question_text: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On arrival, she is disoriented but responsive. Six months ago, she received 3 stents for severe coronary heart disease. She reports that she lives alone and has little contact with her family. The admitting physician asks the patient if she has an advance directive and preferences for potential end-of-life care. The patient retrieves a living will from her purse that is consistent with her verbal confirmation that she does not wish to receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation, breathing tube placement, or defibrillation. Two days later, the patient's condition worsens, and she becomes unresponsive. The same day, the patient's neighbor comes to the hospital saying that he is a long-term friend of the patient and just heard that she was admitted to the hospital. He says that the patient's first grandchild was born 3 weeks ago. “She does not get along well with her own children, but it would mean the world to her to know that she has become a grandma. I know she would feel differently about receiving life support now that she has a grandchild.” Which of the following actions would be most appropriate if the patient needed life support?
content_preview: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On arrival, she is disoriented but responsive. Six months ago, she received 3 stents for severe coronary heart disease. She reports that she lives alone and has little contact with her family. The admitting physician asks the patient if she has an advance directive and preferences for potential end-of-life care. The patient retrieves a living will from her purse that is consistent with her verbal confirmation that she does not wish to receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation, breathing tube placement, or defibrillation. Two days later, the patient's condition worsens, and she becomes unresponsive. The same day, the patient's neighbor comes to the hospital saying that he is a long-term friend of the patient and just heard that she was admitted to the hospital. He says that the patient's first grandchild was born 3 weeks ago. “She does not get along well with her own children, but it would mean the world to her to know that she has become a grandma. I know she would feel differently about receiving life support now that she has a grandchild.” Which of the following actions would be most appropriate if the patient needed life support?
hint: A legal document that explicitly states the patient's wishes regarding end-of-life care is available.
learning_objective: Recognize the legal authority of a living will in end-of-life care decisions.

answers.content: Ask the neighbor to verify in writing that the patient wants life support, then provide full resuscitation
answers.explanation_why: When a patient lacks decision-making capacity or does not have a living will, directives by a close friend (e.g., the neighbor) can override a living will, but only if the friend has a durable medical power of attorney from the patient and such a decision is in line with the patient's most recently expressed wishes. In this case, there is no mention of a durable medical power of attorney, and the patient's most recent wish to not receive life support was expressed verbally to the physician. Therefore, the patient's advance directive should be followed.

answers.content: Provide basic life support but do not intubate or defibrillate the patient
answers.explanation_why: Basic life support is a form of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which was explicitly refused by the patient in verbal and written form and should not, therefore, be implemented.

answers.content: Provide full life support until the patient's family can be consulted to assist in the decision
answers.explanation_why: If a patient without decision-making capacity cannot express his or her wishes and does not have a written living will, the patient's next of kin can serve as a surrogate decision-maker. This patient's wishes, however, have already been stated verbally and in a written advanced directive.

answers.content: Provide only comfort measures to the patient
answers.explanation_why: A living will can only be disregarded when it is not in line with a patient's most recently expressed wishes (as stated by the patient) or when a legally appointed durable medical power of attorney (for a patient without decision-making capacity) indicates that the patient's wishes have changed since the living will was last updated. Next of kin can be surrogate decision-makers only if an advance directive is not available and there is no durable medical power of attorney. In this case, this patient has a living will available and also verbally confirmed her wishes to the physician (her verbal statement would count even in the absence of a living will). Therefore, it is not appropriate for the next of kin or a close friend to be the decision-maker in this case, and only comfort measures (e.g., pain medication) should be provided to this patient.

answers.content: Administer vasopressor agents as needed but do not provide other life support
answers.explanation_why: Vasopressor agents are a component of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which has been clearly rejected by the patient verbally and in her written living will. Therefore, vasopressor agents should not be administered.

question_text: A gynecologist is approached by a close personal friend after a church service that they attended together. “You know Marc and I are going on vacation next week. I totally did not see this coming, but I am going to run out of my birth control pill. I am afraid I won't be able to get my prescription filled before we leave because the next few days will be very busy. I know this is awkward, but could you please write me a prescription just to cover the time until I am back from vacation?”. The physician has known the friend for many years and she knows that she has no personal history of serious illness. The friend is an attorney who has a hectic schedule, which the physician sympathizes with. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A gynecologist is approached by a close personal friend after a church service that they attended together. “You know Marc and I are going on vacation next week. I totally did not see this coming, but I am going to run out of my birth control pill. I am afraid I won't be able to get my prescription filled before we leave because the next few days will be very busy. I know this is awkward, but could you please write me a prescription just to cover the time until I am back from vacation?”. The physician has known the friend for many years and she knows that she has no personal history of serious illness. The friend is an attorney who has a hectic schedule, which the physician sympathizes with. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: It is important that a physician always weigh the urgency of the care they are being asked to provide with objectivity towards the patient and the situation.
learning_objective: Recognize when it is inappropriate to prescribe medication to friends or family.

answers.content: Suggest that friend use condoms for contraception during their vacation
answers.explanation_why: Condoms are an alternative form of contraception for this patient. However, physicians should generally avoid making professional consultations to close friends and family because they can be subject to conflict between emotional relationships and objectivity.

answers.content: Inform the friend that it is never appropriate for a physician to be involved in the treatment of a friend or family member
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should generally refrain from the treatment of family and friends because professional objectivity can be clouded by emotion. However, this principle does not apply to all situations, such as when emergency treatment is indicated.

answers.content: Prescribe oral contraceptives if the friend agrees to undergo a proper physical examination
answers.explanation_why: Whenever possible, a thorough physical examination should be performed before prescribing any medication or initiating any treatment. However, even after a thorough physical examination, it would not be appropriate for a physician to prescribe an elective medication to a friend in this case.

answers.content: Prescribe oral contraceptives after ruling out that the friend has any contraindications, but emphasize that this is an exception
answers.explanation_why: Contraindications have to be ruled out before prescribing any medications. However, even after ruling out contraindications, it would not be appropriate for this physician to prescribe elective medication to a friend in this case.

answers.content: Explain that it is not appropriate to prescribe medication to a friend unless in an emergency
answers.explanation_why: According to the American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics, self-treatment, treatment of immediate family, and treatment of close friends should only occur in emergency situations. An emotional relationship with a patient can interfere with a physician's objective judgment. Their relationship may cause the physician or patient to be uncomfortable obtaining a full history and physical exam (e.g., sexual history and genitourinary exam). It is not appropriate for the physician to provide treatment to their friend in this non-emergency situation. In this case, the physician should politely decline while explaining their concerns and help the friend to find a more appropriate physician.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: There are exceptions to when consent from a parent is required before treating a minor.
learning_objective: Recognize when minors can consent to STI treatment without parental notification.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and inform the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient’s parents give consent to treatment
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Thus, informing this patient's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality, and their consent to treatment is not needed.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient meets the criteria for legal emancipation
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); legal emancipation is not required.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient without notifying the patient’s parents or the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why:
Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential (though minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, because this patient has a notifiable disease (Chlamydia trachomatis infection), the physician is required to report the case to a public health official.

Other exceptions to when parental consent is generally not needed for a minor to receive medical care include emergency care, care related to addiction, and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., contraception, pregnancy).

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and his girlfriend and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality. In several states, physicians can also prescribe treatment for certain sexually transmitted infections for a patient's partner even if the partner has not been evaluated by the physician.

question_text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motorcycle collision. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Physical examination shows fixed and bilaterally dilated pupils and an open head wound with visible brain matter in the left occipital region. After transfer to the neurocritical care unit, two full neurological examinations and an apnea test are performed, and brainstem reflexes are absent. The patient is declared brain dead. The attending neurosurgeon speaks to the family and explains the meaning of brain death and that the patient will not recover. His family members say they are hopeful because the patient still moves his fingers when they speak to him or touch his hand. Despite a thorough explanation by the physician that the movements do not indicate brain function, the family believes the patient will recover. Life support is continued while the health care team and the family attempt to reach an agreement. After further argument, the family threatens legal action and says they will physically prevent staff from withdrawing life support, if necessary. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motorcycle collision. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Physical examination shows fixed and bilaterally dilated pupils and an open head wound with visible brain matter in the left occipital region. After transfer to the neurocritical care unit, two full neurological examinations and an apnea test are performed, and brainstem reflexes are absent. The patient is declared brain dead. The attending neurosurgeon speaks to the family and explains the meaning of brain death and that the patient will not recover. His family members say they are hopeful because the patient still moves his fingers when they speak to him or touch his hand. Despite a thorough explanation by the physician that the movements do not indicate brain function, the family believes the patient will recover. Life support is continued while the health care team and the family attempt to reach an agreement. After further argument, the family threatens legal action and says they will physically prevent staff from withdrawing life support, if necessary. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: Brain death is defined as irreversible, complete loss of function of the whole brain. This diagnosis will guide further management, a delicate task that needs careful handling.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when facing a disagreement over life-sustaining measures in brain death.

answers.content: Bring the case to the hospital ethics committee
answers.explanation_why:
When there is a disagreement between the family and the medical team over life-sustaining measures in a patient with established brain death, the American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend seeking consultation from an independent, objective authority, such as an ethics committee. Recommendations also emphasize an empathetic approach that meets the family's emotional needs and tries to reach a mutual understanding.

Although it is medically appropriate to discontinue life-supporting measures after brain death, and the physician is not obligated to obtain the family’s permission, life support may be continued briefly to allow the family time to visit the patient and come to terms with the diagnosis. If disagreement persists despite these accommodations, further steps (e.g., consulting the ethics committee) may be necessary.

answers.content: Discontinue all life-supporting measures and exclude the family from the decision-making process
answers.explanation_why: Discontinuing therapy after brain death is medically appropriate, and the physician does not need to obtain the family's permission to end life-sustaining measures. However, excluding the family without further efforts at communication would be unempathetic and not responsive to the family's emotional needs. The American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend an alternative approach in the case of a difference of opinion over life support in a patient with brain death.

answers.content: Explain that the patient is dead and life support has to be stopped because the treatment of other patients is more important now
answers.explanation_why: Discontinuing therapy after brain death is appropriate, and the reasons for doing so should be communicated transparently and empathetically to the patient's surrogate (in this case, his family). However, this should be done with care and respect for the family's emotional needs. Although the capacities of the health care system are limited and other patients need treatment, it is insensitive and potentially confrontational to tell the family about that at this point. The American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend an alternative approach in the case of a difference of opinion over life support in a patient with brain death.

answers.content: Respect the family’s autonomy and maintain life support indefinitely
answers.explanation_why: The patient, or if applicable his surrogate decision-maker (in this case, the family), should be included in the decision-making process whenever possible, and their autonomy needs to be respected. However, it is medically appropriate to discontinue therapy after brain death.

answers.content: Obtain a CT angiography to confirm absent intracranial blood flow
answers.explanation_why: CT angiography of the brain is an accepted ancillary method for establishing brain death. However, it is not necessary for this patient whose diagnosis has already been properly established by two different neurological examinations showing the absence of brainstem reflexes, and an apnea test. Ancillary brain death tests are only indicated when the neurological examination or the apnea test cannot be performed (e.g., severe facial trauma).

question_text: An attending physician in internal medicine publishes an important study about the efficacy of a new drug used to treat Crohn disease. She is currently treating many patients with inflammatory bowel disease who would benefit greatly from this new treatment. After the study is published, the physician receives a letter from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the medication. The company offers her sponsorship of travel, lodging, and registration to present her research at an important international conference on inflammatory bowel disease. The company also offers her funding for a phase III trial with the new drug at the hospital where she is currently working. The company reserves the right to withhold the publication of the physician's research findings after the trial. The physician is very interested in both the drug trial and the conference, where many potential collaborators would be present that could help assist in her research. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the attending physician?
content_preview: An attending physician in internal medicine publishes an important study about the efficacy of a new drug used to treat Crohn disease. She is currently treating many patients with inflammatory bowel disease who would benefit greatly from this new treatment. After the study is published, the physician receives a letter from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the medication. The company offers her sponsorship of travel, lodging, and registration to present her research at an important international conference on inflammatory bowel disease. The company also offers her funding for a phase III trial with the new drug at the hospital where she is currently working. The company reserves the right to withhold the publication of the physician's research findings after the trial. The physician is very interested in both the drug trial and the conference, where many potential collaborators would be present that could help assist in her research. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the attending physician?
hint: Patients can benefit from collaboration between pharmaceutical companies and physicians. However, clinical research guidelines should be followed to protect the integrity of research, objectivity of the physician's judgment, and general welfare of patients.
learning_objective: Recognize ethical guidelines for physician-industry relationships, and choose the appropriate response to potential conflicts of interest.

answers.content: Reject the trial funding and accept the conference sponsorship but properly disclose the financial support.
answers.explanation_why: The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics states that costs related to travel and accommodation or personal expenses an attending physician incurs related to a conference or meeting should not be paid for by industry. In addition, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

answers.content: Accept trial funding and conference sponsorship if the institutional review board gives permission.
answers.explanation_why: Industry-sponsored research is permissible if there are no conflicts of interest and if the institutional review board gives permission. However, the American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics states that physicians should have complete autonomy over the presentation and publication of the results. This company's stipulations for trial funding jeopardizes the integrity of research. In addition, the AMA Code of Medical Ethics states that reimbursement for travel, accommodation, or other costs an attending physician incurs at a conference or meeting should not be paid for by industry. In addition, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

answers.content: Accept the trial funding and reject the conference sponsorship.
answers.explanation_why: The American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics states that physicians should have complete autonomy over the presentation and publication of results following a clinical trial. This company's stipulations for trial funding would jeopardize the integrity of a potential research study.

answers.content: Reject both the offer for the trial funding and the conference sponsorship.
answers.explanation_why:
The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics states that a physician can accept a gift from industry only if it assists the physician's work and benefits patients. The value of any such gift should not be substantial; pens, notepads, and medical textbooks are examples of acceptable gifts. Consequently, the AMA states that a physician should not accept subsidies from industry for the purpose of underwriting the cost of continuing medical education conferences or professional meetings (e.g., travel, lodging, and registration). Moreover, a pharmaceutical company cannot invite a physician to present at a medical conference. Instead, the institution organizing the conference or meeting may accept commercial support (i.e., from the pharmaceutical company) and independently decide the appropriate use of its funds (e.g., content, presenters, fees, reimbursement).

Physician partnership with pharmaceutical companies has grown exponentially as funding in clinical research activities has expanded. While phase III drug trials are often industry-sponsored, the lead researcher should have complete responsibility for the conduct of the trial, data analysis, and research publication; even unfavorable results from the trial should be reported. The company's stipulations for trial funding jeopardizes the integrity of research. Therefore, the attending physician should not accept the trial funding. Industry-sponsored research is only permissible if there are no conflicts of interest, the institutional review board gives permission, and all sources of funding are duly disclosed.

answers.content: To avoid a potential conflict of interest, recommend that a senior resident attend the conference and lead the trial.
answers.explanation_why: The American Medical Association Code of Medical Ethics permits industry to provide funds (e.g., grants) to academic/training institutions in order to help medical students, residents, and fellows attend an important medical conference. However, to avoid any conflict of interest, the training institution (not an attending physician) where trainees are attending medical school or completing their residency or fellowship must independently select the recipients. In addition, financial assistance should not be given directly from the industry to the attendees. Moreover, a licensed physician must lead a drug trial; it would be inappropriate for a senior resident, who has not yet completed training, to lead a drug trial.

Lab Values

question_text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. She is scheduled to receive vaccinations against hepatitis A, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella. She does not have a fever or a history of serious illness. The physician reviews the recommended immunization schedule with the parents during the visit. They agree to all vaccinations except the one against varicella. When asked about their reason for refusing the varicella vaccine, the father says, “It has nothing to do with the cost. We simply believe that the vaccine is unnecessary. We both had chickenpox as children, and it was no problem. Also, we are homeschooling.” The physician informs the parents of the risks of not vaccinating their daughter against varicella, including the sequelae of chickenpox infection in adults. The parents thank the physician for the information but decline the varicella vaccine for now. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician at this time?
content_preview: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. She is scheduled to receive vaccinations against hepatitis A, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella. She does not have a fever or a history of serious illness. The physician reviews the recommended immunization schedule with the parents during the visit. They agree to all vaccinations except the one against varicella. When asked about their reason for refusing the varicella vaccine, the father says, “It has nothing to do with the cost. We simply believe that the vaccine is unnecessary. We both had chickenpox as children, and it was no problem. Also, we are homeschooling.” The physician informs the parents of the risks of not vaccinating their daughter against varicella, including the sequelae of chickenpox infection in adults. The parents thank the physician for the information but decline the varicella vaccine for now. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician at this time?
hint: It is important to remember that, in an ongoing, respectful relationship between the physician and the parents, there is usually more than one opportunity to talk about a vaccination that is refused.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when parents refuse a recommended vaccination for their child.

answers.content: Respect the parents' decision and defer discussion on varicella vaccination until the patient reaches the age of majority
answers.explanation_why: The physician should respect the parents' decision to not vaccinate their child, as they are free to make decisions about their child's medical care unless that decision puts the child at substantial risk of harm. However, the physician should not defer the discussion until the girl reaches the age of majority. Instead, he or she should attempt to convince the parents of the merits of vaccination and take advantage of their ongoing, respectful relationship to address the refused vaccination at subsequent visits.

answers.content: Inform the parents about the physician's liability for medical negligence and terminate the physician-patient relationship
answers.explanation_why: The physician may be concerned about his or her liability for medical negligence based on treating a child who did not receive a recommended vaccine. This can be addressed by documenting the conversation with the parents about the risks and benefits of vaccinating and not vaccinating and the parents' refusal. Physicians should avoid terminating the physician-patient relationship just because parents refuse to vaccinate their child. This decision should be made only if a substantial level of conflict develops and compromises the physician-patient relationship. Also, if the physician terminates the relationship, he or she needs to provide sufficient notice so that another health care provider can be found.

answers.content: Recommend resources on varicella vaccination and at the next visit ask the parents about administering the vaccination
answers.explanation_why: The physician's role in situations in which parents refuse vaccination for their child should be to explore parental concerns, provide the parents with reliable information about the risks and benefits of vaccination, and attempt to correct misinformation so the parents can make an informed decision. The topic should then be revisited at the next visit. If the parents still refuse vaccination after further discussion, the physician must respect the decision and most situations do not require that coercive measure be taken (e.g., reporting the refusal to the public health agency, involving state agencies to override the parents' decision on the premise of medical neglect, informing child protective services). Coercive measures are usually only required if there is a significant risk of serious harm to the child and/or to others (e.g., diseases with very high morbidity and mortality, vaccines targeting epidemic disease).

answers.content: Accept the parents' decision but report the varicella vaccination refusal to the local public health agency
answers.explanation_why: Coercive measures like reporting the parents' decision to not vaccinate their child to the local public health agency are usually only justified if that decision poses a significant risk of harm to the child or others. In this case, since it is a varicella immunization, it does not pose a significant risk because the population is highly immunized and the prevalence of the disease is low. Therefore, it is not necessary to report this situation to the public health agency.

answers.content: Inform child protective services about the potential for child neglect
answers.explanation_why: Informing child protective services would not be appropriate for this patient or in most cases of vaccination refusal. The physician should only inform child protective services about the potential for child neglect if the decision to not vaccinate puts the child at substantial risk of harm (e.g., refusing the tetanus vaccine in a child who has a puncture wound that is deep and contaminated), which is not the case here.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
hint: The physician must balance responsibility to public safety with the welfare of the individual patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the physician's responsibility regarding a patient's driving capacity and public safety.

answers.content: "You should not feel that you are a burden on your son. I'm sure he will be happy to drive you."
answers.explanation_why: A physician should encourage patients to communicate with their family members and seek help when necessary. However, it is inappropriate for the physician to presume that the patient's son would be willing to drive for the patient. The physician should instead explore the patient's reasons for feeling like a burden on his son, rather than simply instructing him not to feel this way. Moreover, in this case, it is critical to inform the patient that his current condition impairs his ability to drive safely; a different reaction would, therefore, be appropriate.

answers.content: "I understand that you need your car to stay mobile, but without an official evaluation of your driving capacity, you should not be driving anywhere."
answers.explanation_why:
Irrespective of state laws, if a physician believes that a patient cannot drive safely, the physician must share their concerns with the patient and ask them to stop driving until they have been evaluated and treated by a driver rehabilitation specialist. Alternatively, the patient can be recleared for driving by the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles). However, the laws for reporting impaired drivers differ between states.

Most states have voluntary reporting laws, under which a physician is not required to disclose a patient's driving impairment to the state licensing authority but are protected from a breach of patient confidentiality if they do so. Some states have mandatory reporting laws, which require physicians to report any patient with driving impairment to the state licensing authority. In states with voluntary or mandatory reporting laws, the physician can be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not report the driving impairment. A few states do not have any reporting laws and require the physician to obtain the patient's consent before disclosing driving impairment to the authorities. In these states, the physician cannot be held liable for a motor vehicle accident involving the impaired driver if the physician does not have consent to disclose driver impairment.

answers.content: "I have a duty to public safety and unfortunately, I must inform the police that you are still driving."
answers.explanation_why: In states with mandatory reporting laws, the physician has an obligation to report patients with conditions that impair driving ability. However, the state licensing authority (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than the police should be informed in this scenario. The physician needs to inform the police only if the patient divulges a criminal act to the physician (e.g., hit-and-run, alcohol-related car accident).

answers.content: "I would advise you to stop driving, but I cannot tell you what to do. Just be aware that it is solely your responsibility if something bad happens."
answers.explanation_why: When the patient has a condition that limits their ability to drive safely, the physician must advise the patient to stop driving. However, in most states, if the patient continues to drive against medical advice and the physician does not report the patient to state licensing authorities, the physician can also be held liable for injuries that occur from a motor vehicle accident involving the patient.

answers.content: "I understand this is a difficult situation for you, but I have to ask you to surrender your driver's license now."
answers.explanation_why: The physician cannot ask a patient to surrender their driver's license. The state licensing authorities (e.g., Department of Motor Vehicles) rather than a physician should determine the patient's inability to drive safely.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of bed-wetting during the past 3 weeks. The mother is concerned because she has received phone calls from the school that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. Physical examination shows a thin female body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. A few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm in size are present on the vulva. There is no vulvar erythema or discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of bed-wetting during the past 3 weeks. The mother is concerned because she has received phone calls from the school that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. Physical examination shows a thin female body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. A few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm in size are present on the vulva. There is no vulvar erythema or discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: This 9-year-old girl has new-onset nocturnal enuresis, behavioral changes, and features suggestive of condylomata acuminata.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of potential sexual abuse in a child, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.content: Reassure the mother and follow up with the patient
answers.explanation_why: Reassuring the mother and following up with the patient is indicated in primary enuresis (the patient never achieved continence) up to 5 years of age whereas this patient has new-onset secondary enuresis (the patient previously achieved continence) at 9 years of age, which requires further workup. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

answers.content: Interview the patient and mother separately
answers.explanation_why:
This child shows signs of sexual abuse, for which a well-documented patient interview is often the most important piece of evidence. In over 90% of cases, the perpetrator is an individual known to the child or their family. Therefore, it is important to interview the child separately from the parent to allow for a neutral and honest conversation. Furthermore, girls aged 9–12 years are at increased risk for sexual abuse. Behavioral changes that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually acting-out, sexual remarks that are inconsistent with age, problems at school, aggression, regression (e.g., nocturnal enuresis), eating or sleep disturbances, and depression. Medical conditions that should raise concern for sexual abuse include sexually transmitted infections (e.g., condylomata acuminata), pregnancies, recurrent urinary tract infections, and anogenital or oral trauma.

The threshold for investigating any suspected case of child abuse should be very low. The patient interview is followed by a careful physical examination and screening for STIs. Subsequently, the physician must notify Child Protective Services to protect the safety of the child and to ensure further investigation (including a forensic interview).

answers.content: Recommend scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night
answers.explanation_why: Scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night are indicated as first-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

answers.content: Contact hospital social workers
answers.explanation_why: Hospital social work services support patients and their families to cope with difficult situations, including suspected child maltreatment. While involving social workers may be warranted at a later point, another step in management is more urgently indicated.

answers.content: Perform a urine dipstick test and measure serum glucose
answers.explanation_why: Performing a urine dipstick test and measuring serum glucose is indicated for ruling out type 1 diabetes. Secondary enuresis and nocturia, both of which are seen here, may occur in children with type 1 diabetes. However, this girl's additional behavioral changes and physical findings raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before she is assessed for type 1 diabetes.

answers.content: Recommend desmopressin therapy
answers.explanation_why: Desmopressin therapy is indicated as second-line therapy for nocturnal enuresis that is not caused by another medical condition in children older than 5 years of age. This patient's additional behavioral changes and physical findings, however, raise concern for something else that needs to be ruled out before her enuresis is assessed further.

question_text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with locally advanced cancer of the left breast. She has a history of mild hypertension. At the previous visit, she was informed of her cancer diagnosis. The physician recommends mastectomy and initiates a conversation about the procedure. When trying to inform the patient about possible complications from the procedure, the patient interrupts the physician and says, “Doctor, I want to continue with surgery. Please don't tell me how things can go wrong or if I will need chemotherapy in the future. I am already anxious, and all the information will overwhelm me.” Which of the following answer options most accurately describes the correct course of action for the physician in this case?
content_preview: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with locally advanced cancer of the left breast. She has a history of mild hypertension. At the previous visit, she was informed of her cancer diagnosis. The physician recommends mastectomy and initiates a conversation about the procedure. When trying to inform the patient about possible complications from the procedure, the patient interrupts the physician and says, “Doctor, I want to continue with surgery. Please don't tell me how things can go wrong or if I will need chemotherapy in the future. I am already anxious, and all the information will overwhelm me.” Which of the following answer options most accurately describes the correct course of action for the physician in this case?
hint: For most procedures, clinicians are required to obtain informed consent.
learning_objective: Recognize the required components of informed consent.

answers.content: The procedure can be performed because the patient consents to treatment.
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient clearly and voluntarily articulated her will to proceed with surgery, she lacks a prerequisite for providing consent for a medical procedure.

answers.content: The procedure cannot be performed because the patient currently lacks decision-making capacity.
answers.explanation_why: Decision-making capacity is determined by the physician for a specific healthcare-related situation and is a prerequisite for giving informed consent. This patient has articulated understanding of the severity of the situation, surgery as indicated treatment, the possibility of complications, and clearly expresses a choice. There is no indication that her decision-making capacity is currently impaired.

answers.content: The procedure cannot be performed because the patient lacks an understanding of the risks associated with mastectomy.
answers.explanation_why: Clinicians must obtain informed consent from patients before providing medical care whenever possible. This involves assessing decision-making capacity and voluntariness, full disclosure of the details of proposed care (e.g., indications, risk-benefit profile, and alternatives), and ensuring that these are fully understood by the patient. This patient clearly and voluntarily articulated her will to proceed with surgery, but there is no indication that she understands any of the known complications or alternative options. Settings in which informed consent may not be necessary include medical emergencies, physician's use of therapeutic privilege, and a lack of patient legal competence.

answers.content: The procedure cannot be performed because the patient lacks competence.
answers.explanation_why: Competence to make medical decisions is a legal assessment of a patient's ability to make decisions regarding health care in general and is a prerequisite for giving informed consent. Competence to make medical decisions is usually presumed. When an assessment of competence is necessary, it is determined by a judge, not a physician. Competence may need to be verified in patients with severe psychiatric illness and/or cognitive impairment, particularly if a physician seeks to override a patient's refusal of treatment. This patient does not display any features that call into question her competence.

answers.content: The procedure can be performed because emergency treatment is needed.
answers.explanation_why: Medical emergencies may be exempt from informed consent if a patient or a surrogate decision-maker is unable to consent (e.g., unconscious trauma patient with no surrogate present) and immediate treatment is needed. Although this patient's diagnosis eventually poses a risk to her life if left untreated, her condition is not acutely life-threatening, and the proposed procedure is elective, so this exception to informed consent does not apply.

answers.content: The procedure can be performed because therapeutic privilege has been invoked.
answers.explanation_why: Therapeutic privilege is an exception to informed consent in which a physician decides to intentionally withhold information from the patient (e.g., when disclosure of information poses a serious psychologic threat to the patient). In this scenario, the physician has already explained the diagnosis and the indicated treatment to the patient, and has now initiated a discussion about the specifics of the proposed procedure. There is no indication that the physician has intentionally decided to withhold information from the patient.

question_text: A group of investigators designs a small phase 0 trial to evaluate the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of a new drug against pregnancy-induced hypertension. They decide to conduct the study after a renowned journal published the results of an animal trial that showed the drug to be safe and effective in reducing blood pressure in pregnant chimps. No teratogenic effects were reported. The investigators receive a grant from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the drug after the company contractually agrees not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication of the trial in any way. The grant funds are designated to be used for expenses incurred in conducting the study. Other than a grant-drawn salary for the predetermined duration of the trial, no financial or material compensation would be offered to the investigators. The investigators propose to recruit a group of ten healthy pregnant women. Both the study participants and the fathers of their children would be informed in their native language, verbally as well as in writing, about the investigators' industry affiliation, the purpose and design of the study, the benefits and known side effects of the new drug, and the alternative options for treating pregnancy-induced hypertension. The participants would also be informed of their rights to confidentiality, to withdraw from the trial at any time, to free medical treatment as well as financial compensation in the event of harm to them or their fetus, and to decision-making autonomy regarding termination or continuation of the pregnancy, antenatal care, and medical or surgical treatment. For participating in the study, they would be offered subsidized antenatal care with a health care provider of their choosing, and the subsidy would not be stopped even if they were to withdraw after enrolling. The investigators would enroll the prospective participants only after the participant and the child's father confirm their understanding of the provided information and sign a consent form. Which of the following would most likely be the cause for the rejection of this study design by an institutional review board?
content_preview: A group of investigators designs a small phase 0 trial to evaluate the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of a new drug against pregnancy-induced hypertension. They decide to conduct the study after a renowned journal published the results of an animal trial that showed the drug to be safe and effective in reducing blood pressure in pregnant chimps. No teratogenic effects were reported. The investigators receive a grant from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the drug after the company contractually agrees not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication of the trial in any way. The grant funds are designated to be used for expenses incurred in conducting the study. Other than a grant-drawn salary for the predetermined duration of the trial, no financial or material compensation would be offered to the investigators. The investigators propose to recruit a group of ten healthy pregnant women. Both the study participants and the fathers of their children would be informed in their native language, verbally as well as in writing, about the investigators' industry affiliation, the purpose and design of the study, the benefits and known side effects of the new drug, and the alternative options for treating pregnancy-induced hypertension. The participants would also be informed of their rights to confidentiality, to withdraw from the trial at any time, to free medical treatment as well as financial compensation in the event of harm to them or their fetus, and to decision-making autonomy regarding termination or continuation of the pregnancy, antenatal care, and medical or surgical treatment. For participating in the study, they would be offered subsidized antenatal care with a health care provider of their choosing, and the subsidy would not be stopped even if they were to withdraw after enrolling. The investigators would enroll the prospective participants only after the participant and the child's father confirm their understanding of the provided information and sign a consent form. Which of the following would most likely be the cause for the rejection of this study design by an institutional review board?
hint: All aboard the sleepy train… This is a very long question with a lot of words, but the answer lies on the surface for the attentive reader.
learning_objective: Recognize ethical considerations when conducting research in vulnerable populations.

answers.content: Research in a vulnerable population
answers.explanation_why:
Vulnerable populations (e.g., pregnant women, neonates, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, economically or educationally disadvantaged individuals) are at increased risk of harm in clinical trials, and certain safeguards for protection of these populations are set in place by the Office of Human Research Protection (OHRP). Before including pregnant women in clinical trials, preclinical trials in pregnant animals and clinical trials in nonpregnant individuals must have been conducted, and data regarding potential risks has to be available. Because the proposed trial was preceded only by an animal trial in pregnant chimps, it would most likely be rejected by an institutional review board. In addition to the animal trial, phase 0, I, II, and III clinical trials in nonpregnant women should be conducted to ensure the safety of the new drug.

Two of the central ethical requirements for clinical trials are voluntary participation and informed consent. The OHRP safeguards aim to ensure that vulnerable populations are not coerced (e.g., prisoners generally cannot be recruited for studies unless the research investigates health issues directly related to the prison population) and that those who may not be fully capable of informed consent are protected by all means (e.g., neonates can only participate in trials for the purpose of obtaining crucial biomedical knowledge that cannot be obtained by other means or has the potential to provide direct benefit to the neonate without posing any additional risk).

answers.content: Lack of informed consent
answers.explanation_why: Informed consent for participation in research is ensured by the proposed study design, as both parents would be provided with sufficient information (e.g., full description of the purpose and design of the study, benefits and side effects of the drug, treatment options, confidentiality) to allow for an informed, voluntary decision about whether to participate in the study. The information would be provided in the participants' native language in written and spoken form to ensure comprehension and sufficient opportunities for the participants to obtain more information. The participants would only be enrolled in the trial after signing a consent form, which is another requirement for informed consent for research purposes.

answers.content: Conflict of interest
answers.explanation_why: A conflict of interest can arise when researchers accept financial compensation from a pharmaceutical company, as seen here. However, in the proposed study the company has contractually agreed not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication. Moreover, other than a grant-drawn salary, no financial or material compensation is offered to the investigators, and the duration of the trial is predetermined, excluding any incentives to prolong the duration of the trial for financial reasons.

answers.content: Plagiarism
answers.explanation_why: Plagiarism is the unlicensed and/or unauthorized reproduction of someone else’s work for the purpose of passing it off as one’s own original effort. The proposed study is based on the results of a previous study, but its design is significantly different (e.g., involving humans instead of chimps). Plagiarism is not an issue with the study design at this point, although it will be important for the animal trial to be properly cited in the study publication.

answers.content: Participation of healthy individuals
answers.explanation_why: A study design for research in healthy individuals in a phase II or higher clinical trial would most likely be rejected by an institutional review board because those phases involve testing a drug in individuals with a specific condition. However, research in healthy individuals is the standard procedure for phase 0 and phase I clinical trials, and an institutional review board would not reject the proposed study design for this reason.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting, but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting, but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation?
hint: In the absence of an oral or written advance directive for a deceased individual, a surrogate decision-maker (SDM) should be designated to act in their best interest. An SDM may be designated by a patient prior to loss of capacity (e.g., durable medical power of attorney), legally appointed (a court-appointed guardian), or appointed via default sequence among the next of kin.
learning_objective: Recognize the hierarchy of surrogate decision-makers in organ donation when advance directives are absent.

answers.content: Encourage another family meeting with a social worker
answers.explanation_why: If there is a disagreement between the next of kin on the most appropriate course of action, it is appropriate for the physician to first encourage a meeting between disagreeing family members with the aim of reaching an agreement about what the deceased would have desired. However, such a meeting has already been arranged, and there are no grounds to assume that a second meeting with a social worker would provide further clarification. Most states generally establish a clear hierarchy for who would be assigned as the SDM among the next of kin.

answers.content: Initiate organ procurement procedures
answers.explanation_why: It would be appropriate to proceed with the organ procurement process if the parents had consented to organ donation because parents are generally considered the highest priority SDMs after spouses. In this scenario, a different action is appropriate in most states.

answers.content: Request a court-appointed guardian
answers.explanation_why: It is appropriate to request a court-appointed guardian for a patient who lacks the capacity to make medical decisions when there is no medical power of attorney or next of kin available to serve as the SDM. In this scenario, the patient has multiple family members involved, some of whom qualify to be SDMs, so it would not be necessary to request a court-appointed guardian.

answers.content: Do not proceed with organ donation
answers.explanation_why: If the patient lacks decision-making capacity or is deceased and does not have advance directives, a self-appointed SDM, or court-appointed SDM, the next of kin becomes their SDM. Most states have established a hierarchy to assign a next of kin as the SDM, although the order may vary from state to state. Spouses are most often listed first, followed by adult children, parents, adult siblings, and close friends. Fiancés and nonlegal partners are not considered spouses in most states, and adulthood is typically defined as 18 years of age. In this case, the patient's parents, who are not in favor of organ donation, would serve as this patient's representatives. The organ donation process should therefore be stopped.

answers.content: Request the patient’s son to intercede and make a decision
answers.explanation_why: Although mature or emancipated minors can, in some states, under rare circumstances, be appointed as SDMs, individuals under 18 years of age are generally considered legally incompetent to make medical decisions. This patient's son is 17 years of age and not considered a mature or emancipated minor, so another person would be designated as the SDM.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of lower back pain. The pain wakes him up at night and radiates down to his legs. During this time, he has also had stiffness of his back muscles. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles bilaterally. The physician decides to prescribe acetaminophen. During a follow-up examination, the patient reports feeling somewhat better but says he is “a bit tired and sleepy throughout the day.” The physician reviews the patient's prescription and notices that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of lower back pain. The pain wakes him up at night and radiates down to his legs. During this time, he has also had stiffness of his back muscles. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles bilaterally. The physician decides to prescribe acetaminophen. During a follow-up examination, the patient reports feeling somewhat better but says he is “a bit tired and sleepy throughout the day.” The physician reviews the patient's prescription and notices that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This elderly patient with acute lumbosacral radiculopathy was inadvertently prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a muscle relaxant, instead of a nonopioid analgesic (medication error).
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of disclosing medical errors to patients.

answers.content: Disclose the error to the patient
answers.explanation_why:
A medication error occurs when the patient receives the wrong drug or the correct drug at an incorrect dose, frequency, and/or via an incorrect route. Physicians should disclose medical errors to patients regardless of the outcome of the error, so disclosure should be the first step even though this patient feels better and only has some drowsiness. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly stating that an error has occurred, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the physician-patient relationship and patient safety.

Medication errors can occur at any of the stages of drug prescription (ordering, transcribing, dispensing, administering). The physician should also report this error via an incident reporting system. If the cause of an error is not immediately known, the physician should inform the patient and maintain contact while investigations carried out. A root-cause analysis should be performed, and appropriate strategies should be implemented to prevent the medication error from recurring (e.g., medication reconciliation at transitions of care, the use of a computerized provider order entry).

answers.content: Switch medication to acetaminophen
answers.explanation_why: The physician can prescribe acetaminophen for the treatment of this patient's acute lumbosacral radiculopathy, as originally intended. Unlike cyclobenzaprine, acetaminophen does not commonly cause drowsiness and would, therefore, be an appropriate choice for this patient. However, this action does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.

answers.content: Continue with the current drug regimen
answers.explanation_why: The physician likely should not continue the current drug regimen. Although cyclobenzaprine can be used to treat acute lumbosacral radiculopathy, cyclobenzaprine is generally avoided in elderly patients because of the risk of sedation, which this patient is experiencing. Before prescribing any drug, the patient should be informed of the risks and benefits in order to make fully informed decisions.

answers.content: Prescribe a topical analgesic ointment
answers.explanation_why: The physician can prescribe a topical analgesic ointment, which may be part of a stepwise approach in conservative treatment of lumbosacral pain. However, this action does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.

answers.content: Refer the patient to physical rehabilitation
answers.explanation_why: The physician can refer the patient to physical rehabilitation, which may be helpful for managing his acute lumbosacral radiculopathy. However, referring the patient to a different specialist does not directly address the fact that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Another step is required first.

question_text: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
content_preview: A 31-year-old homeless and uninsured man is brought to the emergency department because he was found agitated and yelling for help. He is well known to the emergency department and has been in and out of the hospital 6 times in the past month for various issues. He has used up his allotted health care assistance program limit and has an outstanding debt to the hospital. When the physician speaks to him, the man states that he just used some drugs that his friend gave him and now has chest pain. Except for illicit drug use, his past medical history is unknown. He appears unkempt. He is diaphoretic and malodorous but oriented to time, place, and person. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician?
hint: This patient with chest pain and diaphoresis might have acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which is a potentially life-threatening condition.
learning_objective: Recognize the obligations under EMTALA to screen and stabilize emergency medical conditions.

answers.content: "We will need to set up health insurance coverage for you with the county healthcare assistance program before treating you."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's health insurance coverage. Once the patient is stabilized, it would be appropriate to assist him in finding additional healthcare coverage (e.g., through a county healthcare assistance program for low-income patients).

answers.content: "We will treat you to the best of our ability, but we will not be liable in the event of medical negligence."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS). The hospital and/or treating physician may still be held liable in the event of medical negligence.

answers.content: "We will check your vital signs and do a workup of your chest pain, but we will have to deny further treatment if the cause of your chest pain is not a medical emergency."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is obligated to screen for emergency medical conditions if requested and, if such a condition exists, provide treatment until that condition is stabilized. Failure to diagnose and treat ACS would endanger this patient's life. The EMTALA defines an emergency medical condition as a medical condition that manifests with acute symptoms (including pain and labor contractions) that are sufficiently severe to (i) place the health of the individual or unborn child in serious jeopardy, (ii) seriously impair bodily functions, or (iii) cause serious dysfunction of an organ or body part.

answers.content: "We will help you get transferred to the nearest hospital, but we cannot treat you since you have used up your allotted health care assistance program limit at our hospital."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's financial limitations. Transferring the patient to another hospital is appropriate if the hospital is not equipped or staffed to properly evaluate and treat a patient's condition.

answers.content: "We will treat you only if you commit to enrolling in a drug rehabilitation program."
answers.explanation_why: According to the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), any hospital with an emergency department is legally obligated to evaluate and stabilize an acute medical emergency (e.g., ACS), regardless of the patient's willingness to participate in a drug rehabilitation program. Once the patient is stabilized, it is appropriate to assist him in enrolling in such a program.
