question_text: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?
hint: This patient wants to discontinue her participation in a human subjects research study. The investigator should follow the guidelines set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP).
learning_objective: Recognize a participant's right to withdraw from a clinical trial, and choose the appropriate follow-up actions.

answers.content: Ask the participant if she is willing to undergo any follow-up evaluation
answers.explanation_why: A participant has a right to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time. The investigator should accept the decision without attempting to influence the participant in any way but may inquire about the reason for withdrawal to identify any potential risks or adverse events. In addition, the investigator should clarify whether the participant wants to withdraw completely (i.e., from all aspects of the study including follow-up) or only partially. Follow-up is important for ensuring the validity of the research and identifying adverse events that could negatively affect other participants. Informed consent on partial participation should be obtained. In the event of complete withdrawal, the participant should not be contacted for further study-related activities, and no additional information should be collected about them. The information collected to date may be kept.

answers.content: Unblind the participant by revealing which group she was in
answers.explanation_why: The protocol for unblinding is determined by the institutional review board at the beginning of a trial. Specific circumstances, such as a subject's pregnancy or adverse events that affect safety, may require unblinding participants. Investigators may also decide to unblind participants after completion of the trial. However, withdrawal from a study is not an obligatory reason to unblind the participant and another action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Offer remaining compensation for subsequent visits
answers.explanation_why:
The type of compensation is determined prior to study enrollment and should be uniformly applicable to all participants. Prorated compensation is used for studies involving multiple visits. This compensation model equitably distributes compensation among participants and pays participants a predetermined amount for each procedure and/or visit. With this compensation model, a participant who wishes to withdraw completely from the study should not be denied compensation that they have already earned but should not be offered compensation for the subsequent visits because such an action may go against the principle of justice for the other participants and risks imposing an element of undue influence on the withdrawing participant to remain (either completely or partially) in the study. Another action is necessary before discussing compensation.

Regardless of the type of compensation model used, a study participant may be eligible for additional compensation if they experienced adverse events from the intervention.

answers.content: Consult the institutional review board overseeing the trial
answers.explanation_why: All clinical trials are required to have institutional review board (IRB) approval before enrolling participants and conducting research. The IRB should be notified in the event of a protocol deviation (e.g., including a participant who does not meet the required criteria, dosing error) or adverse event. Although study withdrawal should be documented, participants are allowed to withdraw from studies without prior consultation with the IRB.

answers.content: Destroy all clinical and diagnostic data collected on the participant so far
answers.explanation_why: Study participants may withdraw at any time, and all data gathered about them should be secured. To ensure patient confidentiality, it may be further necessary to anonymize the data. However, the FDA and OHRP guidelines for clinical drug trials stipulate that all data collected prior to withdrawal must remain in the study database to ensure validity of the research and enable intention-to-treat analysis if needed.

question_text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a generalized seizure 3 hours ago. The episode lasted for 1 minute and was followed by nonbloody vomiting. The mother reports that the seizure started after the boy fell down the stairs while crawling around the house. He has also become increasingly irritable and refused to feed for the past few days. She says there have not been other episodes of seizure or history of trauma. The boy's immunizations are up-to-date. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. He has a pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple purple and yellow skin discolorations around his chest and back at the level of the 6^th rib bilaterally. Results of initial laboratory studies are pending. CT scan of the head shows a thin, extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses the cranial sutures on the anterolateral aspect of the left hemisphere. In addition to intensive care and neurosurgical consultation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a generalized seizure 3 hours ago. The episode lasted for 1 minute and was followed by nonbloody vomiting. The mother reports that the seizure started after the boy fell down the stairs while crawling around the house. He has also become increasingly irritable and refused to feed for the past few days. She says there have not been other episodes of seizure or history of trauma. The boy's immunizations are up-to-date. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. He has a pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple purple and yellow skin discolorations around his chest and back at the level of the 6th rib bilaterally. Results of initial laboratory studies are pending. CT scan of the head shows a thin, extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped, heterogeneous lesion that crosses the cranial sutures on the anterolateral aspect of the left hemisphere. In addition to intensive care and neurosurgical consultation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: An extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped lesion that crosses the cranial sutures is consistent with a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is typically caused by tears in bridging veins due to sudden acceleration and/or deceleration. Without a plausible history, SDH in conjunction with bruises (purple and yellow skin discoloration) around the thorax at the level of the same rib (indicating a firm grip at this region) should raise concerns for shaken baby syndrome (SBS), a form of physical child abuse.
learning_objective: Recognize shaken baby syndrome, and choose the appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.content: Perform genetic testing for bleeding disorders
answers.explanation_why: This patient's bruises and SDH may be caused by a bleeding disorder. His platelet count and coagulation parameters (PT/INR, PTT) should be measured as a part of the initial workup to rule out bleeding disorders and in preparation for potential surgery. However, genetic testing for a bleeding disorder is not required unless the results of the initial workup suggest a bleeding disorder. This patient's initial laboratory workup is pending.

answers.content: Perform skeletal survey radiographs
answers.explanation_why: In SBS, nonfebrile seizures, vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding can be the result of increased intracranial pressure due to the SDH (if the anterior fontanelle is closed) or due to diffuse axonal injury (which might not be evident on CT scan). Children below 2 years of age are prone to developing traumatic brain injury if they are shaken violently because they have a relatively large head, poor neck tone, increased water content of the brain, and flat skull base (which permits the brain to move easily). After stabilizing the patient, a skeletal survey and fundoscopy should be performed in all cases of suspected child abuse in order to evaluate for signs that cannot be detected on physical examination. Findings that support physical child abuse include multiple fractures at different stages of healing, metaphyseal and epiphyseal corner fractures, posterior rib fractures, spiral diaphyseal fractures of long bones (e.g., humerus), retinal hemorrhage, and vitreous hemorrhage. Suspected child abuse warrants an immediate notification of Child Protective Services.

answers.content: Arrange for a meeting with both parents
answers.explanation_why: This patient's clinical and imaging findings suggest abusive head trauma rather than a fall down the stairs as stated by the mother. At this point, it is highly unlikely that talking to both parents will help clarify the circumstances of the incident. Moreover, confronting the parents with doubts about the truthfulness of their statements could make them avoid further contact with the physician and thereby delay further evaluation and treatment for the boy.

answers.content: Perform lumbar puncture
answers.explanation_why: This patient has an SDH, which is a contraindication for lumbar puncture.

answers.content: Perform electroencephalography
answers.explanation_why: Electroencephalography (EEG) is used to diagnose epileptic disorders and to risk-stratify patients with epileptic disorders for future seizures. In a child with a seizure, an EEG is performed after febrile seizures, CNS infections, and toxic, metabolic, and structural causes for a seizure have been ruled out by the initial workup (e.g., serum electrolytes and glucose, neuroimaging). This patient's initial workup reveals SDH, which is a structural cause of seizures. An EEG is therefore not required.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with mesothelioma 6 months ago. Since that time, he has been treated with oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. He appears tired but is not in acute distress. Pulse oximetry on oxygen at 1 L/min via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. The patient has mild dyspnea when he speaks but is alert and fully oriented. Auscultation of the lungs discloses fine crackles in the bases of both lungs. The physician recommends increasing the patient's oxygen therapy to 2–3 L/min via nasal cannula. Six hours after the visit, the patient's daughter calls the office and requests a copy of her father's medical records, so she can settle an issue with her father's health insurer. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with mesothelioma 6 months ago. Since that time, he has been treated with oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. He appears tired but is not in acute distress. Pulse oximetry on oxygen at 1 L/min via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. The patient has mild dyspnea when he speaks but is alert and fully oriented. Auscultation of the lungs discloses fine crackles in the bases of both lungs. The physician recommends increasing the patient's oxygen therapy to 2–3 L/min via nasal cannula. Six hours after the visit, the patient's daughter calls the office and requests a copy of her father's medical records, so she can settle an issue with her father's health insurer. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: When responding to the daughter's request, the physician should be mindful of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).
learning_objective: Recognize the conditions under which a patient's medical records can be released according to HIPAA.

answers.content: "Can you tell me what the issue is with your father's health insurer?"
answers.explanation_why: As per the HIPAA Privacy Rule, the physician does not need to know the reason for the request to access medical records in order to make a decision about providing access.

answers.content: "I can send a copy of your father's medical records to his health insurer within the next 30 days."
answers.explanation_why: When a covered entity (e.g., health plan, health care clearinghouse) requests access to protected health information (PHI), the minimum necessary standard of HIPAA requires healthcare providers to limit access to and disclosure of PHI to what is necessary to accomplish a particular task. It would not be appropriate for the physician to disclose PHI without a direct request from the health insurer or to send the patient's medical records in their entirety to the health insurer.

answers.content: "I can release your father's medical records if he requests them himself."
answers.explanation_why:
According to the HIPAA Privacy Rule, patients have the legal right to obtain copies of their protected health information (PHI) such as medical records. However, the release of a patient's PHI to an unauthorized individual (e.g., a family member who is not a surrogate decision maker, a healthcare provider who is not involved in the patient's care) is contingent upon the patient themself providing written or verbal consent to share the information. This is done in order to protect the patient's confidentiality.

In accordance with HIPAA, exceptions to the information that can be accessed by a patient include notes taken by a mental health care provider during psychotherapeutic counseling and information gathered in expectation of a probable civil, criminal, or administrative claim or process.

answers.content: “I can send a copy of your father's medical records to his home address within the next 30 days.”
answers.explanation_why: Although the HIPAA Privacy Rule allows patients to access their medical records and places a 30-day time limit within which the medical records should be released by the hospital or physician practice once the request is made, the request should only be granted if the patient himself or an authorized representative makes the request.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision, headaches, and chest pain for the past 3 days. He takes enalapril for hypertension but did not take his medications for a week because he did not have time to collect his new box of tablets from the pharmacy. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 202/116 mm Hg. Fundoscopy shows optic disc blurring and retinal hemorrhages. He is admitted to the hospital for continuous cardiac monitoring and a labetalol infusion is initiated. The next day, his blood pressure decreases to 155/92 mm Hg and the physician directs the nurse on call to discontinue intravenous labetalol and reinitiate daily 15 mg oral enalapril treatment. Which of the following responses is most appropriate by the nurse?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision, headaches, and chest pain for the past 3 days. He takes enalapril for hypertension but did not take his medications for a week because he did not have time to collect his new box of tablets from the pharmacy. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 202/116 mm Hg. Fundoscopy shows optic disc blurring and retinal hemorrhages. He is admitted to the hospital for continuous cardiac monitoring and a labetalol infusion is initiated. The next day, his blood pressure decreases to 155/92 mm Hg and the physician directs the nurse on call to discontinue intravenous labetalol and reinitiate daily 15 mg oral enalapril treatment. Which of the following responses is most appropriate by the nurse?
hint: The most appropriate response is the one that minimizes the likelihood of medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of closed-loop communication to minimize medical errors.

answers.content: "Of course. I will discontinue the labetalol infusion and start the patient on oral enalapril."
answers.explanation_why: While the nurse has repeated the names and routes of medications back to the physician, there is additional information about the medication that should also be reiterated. A comprehensive response is important to allow the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the information correctly.

answers.content: "I will put the patient on an oral ACE inhibitor, QD immediately."
answers.explanation_why: While the nurse has generally referenced the correct medication type and frequency, this response is not specific enough for the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the information correctly. A comprehensive response is important to help prevent communication errors and to allow the sender of the information to verify accuracy.

answers.content: "I will do it right away."
answers.explanation_why: This response is ambiguous and does not allow the physician to verify that the nurse heard the information and understood it correctly.

answers.content: "I will stop the labetalol infusion and put the patient on 15 mg daily oral enalapril."
answers.explanation_why: This statement is an example of closed-loop communication, an error prevention technique in which the listener repeats the information received back to the speaker. The nurse (i.e., the listener) reiterates the name and route of the medication to be discontinued and the name, route, dosage, and frequency of the medication to be reinitiated. Doing so allows the speaker (i.e., the physician) to verify if the information was understood correctly. Closed-loop communication is important for preventing communication errors in other situations as well, including during cardiopulmonary resuscitation, during trauma management, and in the operating room.

answers.content: "I will write down the order and change the medications right after the morning rounds."
answers.explanation_why: This response does not allow the physician to verify that the nurse has heard and understood the medication information correctly. A comprehensive response is important to help prevent communication errors and to allow the sender of information to verify accuracy.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: In the United States, adolescents are able to provide consent for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
learning_objective: Recognize adolescents' rights to consent for STI treatment and confidentiality, and choose the appropriate management for gonococcal infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but they can still legally request records about your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: This patient's information is confidential and should not be shared with his parents unless he gives consent. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents only if you are legally emancipated."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; legal emancipation is not required.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but I am obligated to inform your partner of your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; parental consent is not required. Furthermore, all individuals who have had sexual contact with patients diagnosed with Neisseria gonorrhea in the 60 days preceding the diagnosis should be evaluated and treated. However, these individuals should be notified via a public health official or by the index patient, not by the physician. In most states, expedited partner therapy for gonococcal infection treatment is allowed to facilitate partner management and prevent further infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics only if one of your parents consents."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs. Thus, parental consent is not required. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, and I recommend that your partner get tested."
answers.explanation_why:
Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of addiction and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., STIs, contraception, pregnancy); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential from his parents (although minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is a reportable disease, the physician is required to report the case to a public health official. Ideally, all of the patient's sexual partners within the past 60 days should be informed (either by the patient or by the public health official, but not by the physician!), evaluated for gonococcal infection, and treated if positive. Alternatively, the physician could provide expedited partner therapy (EPT), especially if the likelihood of follow-up is low.

Intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone is used both for targeted and empirical therapy for gonococcal infection. If chlamydial coinfection is present or has not been ruled out, oral doxycycline is added. If EPT is required, a single dose of oral cefixime can be administered instead of ceftriaxone. If chlamydial infection is present or has not been excluded in the patient's partner, doxycycline (preferred) or azithromycin should be added.

question_text: A 74-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 5-week history of fever, fatigue, and cough with purulent sputum. He has not seen a doctor in 5 years. He appears thin. Chest x-ray shows a patchy infiltrate in the left lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum reveals acid-fast bacilli. Polymerase chain reaction confirms the diagnosis of respiratory tuberculosis and the patient is placed in an airborne infection isolation room. A nurse and a medical student enter the patient's room to insert a urinary catheter. While preparing to insert the catheter, the student notices that the nurse has put on nonsterile gloves. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the medical student?
content_preview: A 74-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 5-week history of fever, fatigue, and cough with purulent sputum. He has not seen a doctor in 5 years. He appears thin. Chest x-ray shows a patchy infiltrate in the left lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum reveals acid-fast bacilli. Polymerase chain reaction confirms the diagnosis of respiratory tuberculosis and the patient is placed in an airborne infection isolation room. A nurse and a medical student enter the patient's room to insert a urinary catheter. While preparing to insert the catheter, the student notices that the nurse has put on nonsterile gloves. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the medical student?
hint: Urinary catheter insertion is an aseptic procedure. Sterile technique, including wearing sterile gloves, should be maintained. Any break in the sterile field jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize and address breaches in sterile technique to ensure patient safety.

answers.content: "I believe you accidentally put on the wrong gloves."
answers.explanation_why: Whenever a person witnesses a medical error, they should directly inform the health care provider who committed the error. This should be done politely and without regard for workplace hierarchy, interpersonal relationships, or the potential of a career setback. A witness who fails to act is also culpable for the consequences of the error. Early medical error reporting can offer a chance for rectification (e.g., replacing nonsterile gloves with sterile gloves) and prevent a near miss (e.g., break of sterile technique) from becoming an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Patient safety (nonmaleficence) is the foremost priority; a safety culture fosters the reporting of both active errors (as seen here) and latent errors.

answers.content: “I suggest we perform a root cause analysis to make sure this error does not happen again.”
answers.explanation_why: Analysis of medical errors (e.g., root cause analysis) is in line with good safety culture and necessary to prevent future errors. However, a root cause analysis is performed after a procedure has been completed. Another reaction is more appropriate at this point in time.

answers.content: “I am really sorry, but I have to report your mistake to the head nurse to ensure transparent communication.”
answers.explanation_why: It is necessary to report of medical errors (e.g., through an incident reporting system), and doing so is in line with good safety culture. However, reporting the error to the head nurse at this step in the procedure delays the possibility of rectifying the error and increases the risk that a near miss (e.g., break in sterile technique) becomes an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the person who committed the error to report it. It would be more appropriate for the student to give the nurse the chance to self report the error at a later time.

answers.content: “Let’s go over everything again to make sure we did not forget something before we insert the catheter."
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not directly address the problem that sterile technique has not been followed, which may convey the assumption that the procedure has not been compromised. Whenever a medical error is witnessed, the witness of the error should speak up. Addressing the error immediately makes rectification possible.

answers.content: “Do you need any help with the insertion of the catheter?”
answers.explanation_why: Collaboration across teams is necessary, and it is generally appropriate for the student to offer to help the nurse. However, urinary catheter insertion should be performed using sterile technique, which includes wearing sterile gloves. This nurse just put on nonsterile gloves. Any break in sterile technique jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error. Another reaction is more appropriate at this stage of the procedure.

question_text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician?
hint: A patient with decision-making capacity has the right to full medical disclosure unless there is a good reason to withhold information.
learning_objective: Recognize the patient's right to medical disclosure, and choose the appropriate response to family requests for nondisclosure.

answers.content: "I will respect your wish to withhold the diagnosis from your father."
answers.explanation_why: Patients with decision-making capacity have the right to full disclosure and, therefore, the right to know their diagnosis based on the principle of autonomy. Because there is no evidence to suggest that this patient lacks decision-making capacity, the son does not have the right to make medical decisions for his father.

answers.content: "I can help you disclose the diagnosis to your father. He has a right to know."
answers.explanation_why: The physician has a duty to directly disclose a diagnosis to a patient. Transferring this responsibility to a relative of the patient is inappropriate and unprofessional. It can, however, be beneficial to include family members in the discussion to bridge any communication gaps or for emotional support, as long as the patient has consented to the physician disclosing health information to family members.

answers.content: "Can you tell me why you don't want your father to know about the diagnosis?"
answers.explanation_why: Patient autonomy is one of the four core principles of medical ethics. When a patient's family or friends make a request for nondisclosure, it is critical to understand why the request has been made because this will inform physicians of how best to approach disclosure while respecting cultural differences or other concerns. Understanding the motivation behind such requests may also uncover explicit reasons not to tell the patient (e.g., grounds for invoking therapeutic privilege, patient preference to not know the diagnosis). Furthermore, it promotes rapport and a trusting relationship with the family. In most cases, cognitively intact patients should be informed of the diagnosis so that they can make appropriate medical decisions. Practical approaches to disclosing a sensitive diagnosis include understanding the patient's preference and incremental disclosure (SPIKES protocol).

answers.content: "As his physician, I cannot withhold any information about your father's health from him."
answers.explanation_why: Cognitively intact patients have the right to know their diagnosis. However, the son's request for nondisclosure raises concern for cultural or personal considerations that the physician might be unaware of. In addition, disregard for the son's request may hurt any established or potential physician-family relationship that could be beneficial moving forward. Other approaches should be considered before disclosing the diagnosis to the patient.

answers.content: "I propose a psychiatric consultation to assess your father's mental competence."
answers.explanation_why: A psychiatric consultation is beneficial to patients with active psychiatric conditions that might undermine or interfere with their decision-making capacity. For patients with a psychiatric history, engaging their primary psychiatrist can help to ascertain their baseline capacity. Although this patient has a history of psychiatric illness, his mental status is currently stable and there is no other evidence to suggest that a psychiatric disorder is impairing his decision-making. A psychiatric consultation at this time would not be appropriate.

question_text: A 62-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with a rare type of bladder cancer comes to a urology cancer center for further diagnostics and treatment. Cystoscopy with biopsies discloses urachal adenocarcinoma in a locally advanced stage. The physician explains that there is currently no standard treatment for the patient's cancer. His only chance of curative treatment is to participate in a clinical trial using a novel operation technique to remove the tumor. After full disclosure of the experimental protocol, the potential hazards and benefits, and discussion of alternative treatment options, the patient consents to participate in the study. One year after the surgery has been successfully performed and during the second-to-last follow-up examination of the trial, the patient tells the physician that he does not want to participate in the study any longer. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with a rare type of bladder cancer comes to a urology cancer center for further diagnostics and treatment. Cystoscopy with biopsies discloses urachal adenocarcinoma in a locally advanced stage. The physician explains that there is currently no standard treatment for the patient's cancer. His only chance of curative treatment is to participate in a clinical trial using a novel operation technique to remove the tumor. After full disclosure of the experimental protocol, the potential hazards and benefits, and discussion of alternative treatment options, the patient consents to participate in the study. One year after the surgery has been successfully performed and during the second-to-last follow-up examination of the trial, the patient tells the physician that he does not want to participate in the study any longer. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: This patient is competent and has made a decision about his participation in the clinical trial.
learning_objective: Recognize a patient's right to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time.

answers.content: "You can withdraw from your decision to participate in this study at any time."
answers.explanation_why:
Acknowledging this patient's right to withdraw from the clinical trial at any time is the most appropriate response in this case. According to regulations established by the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP) of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, all subjects enrolled in a study have the right to discontinue their participation at any given time, for any or no reason, without incurring a penalty or loss of benefit which they were entitled to for participating in the study. The investigator cannot obtain any further information without the subject's consent.

If the study is not subject to Food and Drug Administration (FDA) review and the subject requests that the data already collected be destroyed, the investigator may honor the subject's requests depending on the protocol set up by the institutional review board. For studies subject to FDA review, the investigator cannot destroy this information or exclude it from analysis. For interventional studies, data regarding adverse events might be important to protect the safety of other research subjects, and the OHRP, therefore, recommends that the investigator clarify with the subject whether they wish to withdraw completely from the trial or only from the primary interventional component. If the subject wishes to withdraw only from the primary interventional component, follow-up data collection can continue after reobtaining the subject's consent.

answers.content: "Can you tell me why you consented to participate if you don't want to complete the study after all?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient's change of mind and refusal of potentially life-saving treatment may warrant further inquiry from the physician; however, it should not intimidate or put any emotional pressure on the patient.

answers.content: "I will have to consult with our research ethics committee before you can withdraw from the study."
answers.explanation_why: A patient is allowed to withdraw from a clinical study at any point and does not require an ethics committee approval to do so.

answers.content: ”Withdrawal from the study after you gave your consent would be a breach of contract.”
answers.explanation_why: Withdrawing from a clinical study at any point is the patient's legal right, and it would not constitute a breach of any agreement.

answers.content: "Please reconsider your decision as your participation in this study could help many other people with your condition."
answers.explanation_why: Although a patient's withdrawal from a clinical trial may have an impact on further results of the study, it does not allow the physician to disregard their decision to quit.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician for a regular health checkup 1 year after establishing care at the office. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary heart disease. Her current medication includes metformin, enalapril, and aspirin. She has brought laboratory results from a screening examination performed 2 weeks ago prior to donating blood. Laboratory studies from the blood bank show a nonreactive HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay and a nonreactive HIV-1/2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. While reviewing the patient's chart, the physician notices that an HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay, which was performed at last year's office visit by a colleague, was reactive. During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: The failure to provide full disclosure in a timely manner constitutes a medical error. The right action in this scenario is grounded in the principles of professional respect and a systems-based approach toward medical error.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of addressing medical errors through professional communication, and choose the appropriate steps to disclose such errors to the patient.

answers.content: Request that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: A medical error should be promptly disclosed to the patient, regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm. The clinician should explain the error and any consequences and allow time for further discussion and questions. Requesting that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test is inappropriate because it would unnecessarily delay patient notification.

answers.content: Speak to the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why:
When a clinician suspects a medical error, they must speak privately and nonjudgmentally with the responsible colleague to determine whether an error occurred and why (e.g., misunderstanding or laboratory error). To help reduce the risk of future errors, the clinician should encourage their colleague to report the incident using standard protocol. Most medical errors are caused by failures in health care systems, and incident reporting can contribute to the identification and improvement of systemic issues. If there is no longer a patient-physician relationship with the colleague, the clinician must comply with HIPAA regulations by initially obtaining the patient’s permission to contact the physician.

Additionally, the clinician should inform the patient of the previous test result and discuss its implications, ensuring transparency and prioritizing care. In this scenario, the patient does not have HIV, and no further testing is needed.

answers.content: Report the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test to the state medical board
answers.explanation_why: The physician should report the colleague directly to the state medical board if the colleague is suspected of committing gross misconduct (e.g., billing fraud, bullying, sexual harassment). At this point, this action is inappropriate.

answers.content: Disclose to the patient that a colleague forgot to follow up on the results of the initial HIV test
answers.explanation_why: It is inappropriate to make assumptions about a colleague's actions. Without investigating, the physician cannot definitively know the reason for the error (e.g., lack of follow-up or laboratory error). A different action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Do not inform the patient since the error did not cause harm
answers.explanation_why: Clinicians must inform patients about a medical error regardless of whether it has caused any immediate harm.

question_text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He reports severe pelvic pain and difficulty moving his left leg. He has not lost consciousness since the accident and does not have any other symptoms. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 116/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a shorter left lower extremity compared to the right one, pelvic instability on palpation, and an inguinal hematoma. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a FAST scan, imaging of the head and cervical spine, and retrograde urethrography are normal. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left iliac fracture with symphysis diastasis. The patient is admitted to the hospital and scheduled for surgery. His daughter, who is an orthopedic trauma surgeon at the same hospital, comes to see him before the procedure. The patient asks his daughter to perform the surgery because he considers his daughter to be an “excellent surgeon” and believes that she would “act in his best interests.” Despite counseling by the primary attending orthopedic surgeon and the patient's daughter, the patient insists that his daughter perform the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the patient's daughter?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He reports severe pelvic pain and difficulty moving his left leg. He has not lost consciousness since the accident and does not have any other symptoms. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 116/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a shorter left lower extremity compared to the right one, pelvic instability on palpation, and an inguinal hematoma. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a FAST scan, imaging of the head and cervical spine, and retrograde urethrography are normal. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left iliac fracture with symphysis diastasis. The patient is admitted to the hospital and scheduled for surgery. His daughter, who is an orthopedic trauma surgeon at the same hospital, comes to see him before the procedure. The patient asks his daughter to perform the surgery because he considers his daughter to be an “excellent surgeon” and believes that she would “act in his best interests.” Despite counseling by the primary attending orthopedic surgeon and the patient's daughter, the patient insists that his daughter perform the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the patient's daughter?
hint: This patient has an unstable pelvic fracture and requires urgent surgery but insists on a specific course of action. Physicians should generally avoid treating friends or family members. A course of action that balances this ethical principle with the patient's preferences is most appropriate.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action when a family member requests medical treatment from a physician relative.

answers.content: Perform the surgery as the primary attending surgeon
answers.explanation_why: The American Medical Association clearly advises against physicians treating or performing surgery on family members because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Exceptions to this recommendation include medical emergencies in which no other qualified physician is present and treatment of minor conditions. However, in this scenario, another trained specialist is available.

answers.content: Offer to manage the postoperative care of the patient
answers.explanation_why: The American Medical Association clearly advises against physicians treating or performing surgery on family members because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. In this scenario, the patient explicitly asks for his daughter to perform surgery on him. Offering to manage the patient's postoperative care does not address his preferences. In addition, managing the patient's postoperative care places the daughter in the position of serving as the primary decision-maker in the patient's care, raising the aforementioned ethical issues.

answers.content: Recommend a transfer of care to a different hospital
answers.explanation_why: Transferring the patient to a different hospital would unnecessarily delay treatment and not pay respect to the patient's preferences.

answers.content: Seek permission from the primary attending surgeon to be the assistant surgeon in the procedure
answers.explanation_why: Although there is no federal law that prohibits physicians from treating or performing surgery on family members, the American Medical Association clearly advises against it because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Exceptions to this recommendation include medical emergencies in which no other qualified physician is present and treatment of minor conditions. In this scenario, the patient explicitly asks for his daughter to perform surgery on him. By asking the primary attending surgeon if she may assist in the procedure, the daughter manages to balance this ethical principle (avoiding treatment of family members) with patient autonomy (honoring her father's preferences).

answers.content: Inform the patient that it is illegal to perform surgery on a family member
answers.explanation_why: There is no federal law that prohibits physicians from treating or performing surgery on family members, but the American Medical Association clearly advises against it because doing so raises ethical issues of professional objectivity, patient confidentiality, and personal feelings that may cloud judgment. Informing the patient that it is illegal to perform surgery on a family member is inaccurate and does not respect the patient's preferences.

question_text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 6 years ago. Three years ago, when he was no longer able to perform daily tasks and take care of himself, the patient moved in with his daughter, who is his surrogate decision-maker. Over the past year, he has been treated twice for food poisoning. He takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. He appears tired and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry skin and mucous membranes; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. There is a tender, nonblanching, erythematous area over the patient's sacrum with superficial skin loss. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Neurologic examination shows ankle clonus and an ataxic gait. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 9/30. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 116 μm^3, and leukocyte count is 13,800/mm^3 (14% eosinophils). Microscopic evaluation of the stool shows multiple eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum. The patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment and further evaluation. The daughter asks if the patient could be treated at home. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with Alzheimer disease 6 years ago. Three years ago, when he was no longer able to perform daily tasks and take care of himself, the patient moved in with his daughter, who is his surrogate decision-maker. Over the past year, he has been treated twice for food poisoning. He takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. He appears tired and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry skin and mucous membranes; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. There is a tender, nonblanching, erythematous area over the patient's sacrum with superficial skin loss. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation and increased bowel sounds. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Neurologic examination shows ankle clonus and an ataxic gait. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 9/30. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 116 μm3, and leukocyte count is 13,800/mm3 (14% eosinophils). Microscopic evaluation of the stool shows multiple eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum. The patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment and further evaluation. The daughter asks if the patient could be treated at home. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: This patient, who has severe cognitive impairment, has a fish tapeworm infection, which most likely has led to his megaloblastic anemia. He is also dehydrated, malnourished, and has a pressure ulcer, which cannot be explained by his medical history.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of elder neglect, and choose the appropriate agency to contact.

answers.content: Evaluate the patient's eligibility for home hospice care
answers.explanation_why: This patient is malnourished, has advanced Alzheimer dementia, and is almost completely dependent in all activities of daily living. The onset and progression of feeding difficulties is a hallmark of advanced dementia, which has a prognosis similar to other end-of-life conditions such as metastatic cancer and stage IV heart failure (i.e., life expectancy < 6 months); therefore, this patient may be eligible for home hospice care. However, his history of food poisoning, dehydration, and unexplained pressure ulcer make another step in management more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Provide a prescription for necessary medications and discharge the patient
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should consider requests made by surrogate decision-makers if the patient lacks decision-making capacity, which is the case here. However, this patient's unexplained malnutrition and dehydration require further investigation before he is discharged.

answers.content: Notify Adult Protective Services
answers.explanation_why: Older adult abuse, including older adult neglect, is frequently perpetrated by someone with power over and responsibility for the patient (e.g., a caregiver or relative, as seen here). In this case, the patient presents with signs of malnourishment, dehydration, and an unexplained pressure ulcer, all of which should raise suspicion for older adult neglect. In the US, physicians are legally and ethically obligated to report suspected older adult abuse to Adult Protective Services if the patient lives at home or with a relative or to the Long-Term Care Ombudsman programs if the abuse occurred in an institution (e.g., assisted living facility). Apart from investigating complaints, these agencies protect older adults by providing them with social, medical, and legal aid.

answers.content: Obtain the patient's approval for discharge
answers.explanation_why: This patient's Mini-Mental State Examination score suggests he has advanced dementia (i.e., any score below 13/30), which means he most likely lacks decision-making capacity. Therefore, he cannot consent to his own discharge.

answers.content: Reach out to a health care assistance program
answers.explanation_why: Health care assistance programs, which include Medicare and county-specific programs, are financial aid programs designed to improve health care access among low-income individuals. The current state of this patient, who lacks decision-making capacity and is dependent on his daughter for health care, is not the result of a lack of financial resources but neglect; a different step is required in the case of older adult neglect.

question_text: A 65-year old man with advanced prostate cancer is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of dyspnea and severe back pain. He rates his pain as an 8 on a 10 point scale. For the past 2 years, the patient failed to respond to multiple chemotherapy cycles. He was previously independent but now lives with his son and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. His son says that his father's condition “is deteriorating every day” and that he “cannot cope with the stress of taking care of him anymore.” The patient has had progressive loss of mobility and worsening pain for the past 6 months. During this time, he also has had decreased appetite, poor oral intake, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. He spends most of the day in bed and cannot tolerate walking without aid. Current medications include acetaminophen, oxycodone, and a fentanyl patch. He appears pale and malnourished. He is alert and fully oriented. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the spine. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows multiple well-demarcated lesions in both lungs and in several vertebrae. The patient has no living will and says he wants to "die in peace." The physician, son, and the rest of the patient's family agree to start hospice care. Which of the following is the most significant factor that affects eligibility for hospice care in this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year old man with advanced prostate cancer is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of dyspnea and severe back pain. He rates his pain as an 8 on a 10 point scale. For the past 2 years, the patient failed to respond to multiple chemotherapy cycles. He was previously independent but now lives with his son and requires assistance with all activities of daily living. His son says that his father's condition “is deteriorating every day” and that he “cannot cope with the stress of taking care of him anymore.” The patient has had progressive loss of mobility and worsening pain for the past 6 months. During this time, he also has had decreased appetite, poor oral intake, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. He spends most of the day in bed and cannot tolerate walking without aid. Current medications include acetaminophen, oxycodone, and a fentanyl patch. He appears pale and malnourished. He is alert and fully oriented. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the spine. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows multiple well-demarcated lesions in both lungs and in several vertebrae. The patient has no living will and says he wants to "die in peace." The physician, son, and the rest of the patient's family agree to start hospice care. Which of the following is the most significant factor that affects eligibility for hospice care in this patient?
hint: Hospice care eligibility is predominantly defined by the enrollment criteria of health insurers, including Medicare, Medicaid, and private insurance.
learning_objective: Recall the primary eligibility criterion for hospice care.

answers.content: Level of pain
answers.explanation_why: Pain can affect a patient's functional status, qualify of life, and level of distress, all of which may influence a decision to pursue hospice care. However, pain is not a factor that directly affects eligibility for hospice care.

answers.content: Decision-making capacity
answers.explanation_why: A patient's decision-making capacity may influence the decision to pursue hospice care, but it is not a factor that affects eligibility for hospice care. This patient is fully able to express his wishes and appears to have decision-making capacity at this time. If they are eligible, patients who do not have decision-making capacity may also be enrolled in hospice care by their legal decision-making proxy.

answers.content: Availability of family caregivers
answers.explanation_why: Hospice care can be provided in a private home setting, and the availability of family caregivers may influence the decision to pursue hospice care. However, this factor does not affect eligibility for hospice care.

answers.content: Life expectancy
answers.explanation_why: To become eligible for hospice care, a patient must have an estimated life expectancy of < 6 months and decide to forgo therapies that have life-prolonging intent. Life expectancy can be assessed with the help of guidelines that measure the decline in clinical status, dependence on assistance, comorbidities, and certain disease-specific criteria (e.g. metastases in patients who have cancer). Patients may be discharged from hospice programs if their estimated life expectancy increases due to an improvement of their medical condition.

answers.content: Lack of a living will
answers.explanation_why: A living will is a legal document in which individuals describe their wishes regarding their care (e.g., to maintain, withhold, or withdraw life-sustaining treatment) should they become incapacitated. A patient is not required to have a living will to be eligible for hospice care.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department and demands to speak to a doctor immediately without giving any further explanation. When being asked to wait, she briefly sits down before restlessly pacing the room. The patient's medical history is unknown. She appears agitated. She is alert and oriented to person and place. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Initial examination shows dilated pupils that are equal in size and reactive to light. The patient refuses to participate in any further medical examinations. When a nurse attempts to talk to her, she briskly stands up and says to the nurse “I'll kill you if you don't let me speak to a doctor.” The patient remains aggressive despite attempts at deescalation, and she is subsequently physically restrained and chemically sedated with an intramuscular lorazepam injection. In addition to continuous observation of the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department and demands to speak to a doctor immediately without giving any further explanation. When being asked to wait, she briefly sits down before restlessly pacing the room. The patient's medical history is unknown. She appears agitated. She is alert and oriented to person and place. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Initial examination shows dilated pupils that are equal in size and reactive to light. The patient refuses to participate in any further medical examinations. When a nurse attempts to talk to her, she briskly stands up and says to the nurse “I'll kill you if you don't let me speak to a doctor.” The patient remains aggressive despite attempts at deescalation, and she is subsequently physically restrained and chemically sedated with an intramuscular lorazepam injection. In addition to continuous observation of the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with psychomotor agitation and combative behavior. The cause of her symptoms is not known.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step after sedating an agitated patient.

answers.content: Reevaluate the patient when she is no longer sedated
answers.explanation_why: An agitated patient that shows violent behavior and poses an imminent threat to themself or others can be physically restrained and/or chemically sedated if other deescalation methods (e.g., verbal techniques) are unsuccessful. After the patient has calmed down or adequate sedation has been achieved, restraints should be removed immediately. Once the patient is no longer sedated, the physician should then reevaluate the underlying cause of the patient's behavior and decision-making capacity to determine whether she should be admitted or discharged. Admission is appropriate when imminent harm to one's self or others continues and/or if the patient is uncooperative, intoxicated, or demonstrates psychotic behavior. If the patient is no longer combative, the behavior was a result of intoxication, and medical examination finds no abnormalities, discharge is recommended.

answers.content: Admit the patient involuntarily
answers.explanation_why: Involuntary admission is appropriate if the patient poses danger to self or others, is in grave disability (e.g., due to a psychiatric illness), or is in need of acute medical treatment. Although involuntary admission may be appropriate in this case, another step needs to be taken before a decision to admit the patient can be made.

answers.content: Notify law enforcement authorities
answers.explanation_why: It is appropriate to notify law enforcement authorities when an individual poses a serious and imminent threat to a person or the public. Although this patient verbally threatened a staff member, no physical harm occurred and she has already been physically restrained and chemically sedated. She does not pose a serious or imminent threat anymore, so it would not be appropriate to notify law enforcement.

answers.content: Restrain the patient until a court order is obtained
answers.explanation_why: It is inappropriate and illegal to prolong physical and/or chemical restraint of a patient after the patient has calmed down or sedation has been achieved. Moreover, it is not necessary to obtain a court order to physically restrain and/or chemically sedate a patient that poses an immediate threat of danger to self or others.

question_text: A 36-year-old internal medicine resident at a teaching hospital notices that the head of her department has frequently been tired and irritable over the past 6 months. The physician in question has been known for his unorthodox teaching methods. His colleagues describe him as misanthropic and eccentric, but a brilliant diagnostician of rare diseases. One year ago, he had a vascular infarction of his right quadriceps femoris muscle while playing golf, and ever since has a limp and uses a cane to walk. He is recently divorced and does not have any children. Over the past 3 months, the resident has observed the physician secretly taking pills on several occasions. During this period, he has also stopped attending rounds and charting. He often meets his patients at odd hours and has a tendency to be absent for a prolonged duration without telling anyone of his whereabouts or answering his phone, which has led to numerous complaints by his colleagues. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
content_preview: A 36-year-old internal medicine resident at a teaching hospital notices that the head of her department has frequently been tired and irritable over the past 6 months. The physician in question has been known for his unorthodox teaching methods. His colleagues describe him as misanthropic and eccentric, but a brilliant diagnostician of rare diseases. One year ago, he had a vascular infarction of his right quadriceps femoris muscle while playing golf, and ever since has a limp and uses a cane to walk. He is recently divorced and does not have any children. Over the past 3 months, the resident has observed the physician secretly taking pills on several occasions. During this period, he has also stopped attending rounds and charting. He often meets his patients at odd hours and has a tendency to be absent for a prolonged duration without telling anyone of his whereabouts or answering his phone, which has led to numerous complaints by his colleagues. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
hint: The physician in question shows signs of substance use disorder and therefore presents a potential threat to patient safety. Regardless of the workplace hierarchy and Gregory's wrath, the resident should disclose this case to a supervisory entity.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial action when suspecting a colleague of substance use disorder.

answers.content: Record the colleague's behavior in the Physician Quality Reporting System
answers.explanation_why: The Physician Quality Reporting System (PQRS) was a widespread health care quality improvement program that was replaced by the Merit-Based Incentive Payment System (MIPS). Both programs require continuous reporting of clinical measures and aim to provide high-quality and cost-effective patient care by reducing medical errors. Neither program is appropriate for reporting an impaired physician.

answers.content: Notify law enforcement authorities
answers.explanation_why: Law enforcement authorities should be notified immediately if criminal activity is suspected or when an individual poses a serious and imminent threat to a person or the public. Doing so may also be appropriate in other cases of misconduct by health care professionals when other disciplinary measures have failed. This impaired physician is not suspected of criminal activity at the moment, so notifying law enforcement authorities would not be the most appropriate first step.

answers.content: Report the colleague to the local Physician Health Program
answers.explanation_why: Reporting a colleague who is impaired and/or has a potential substance use disorder to the local Physician Health Program (PHP) is the most appropriate initial action by the resident. The PHP is supervised by the state medical board and aims to prevent, detect, and manage disorders that cause impairment in physicians. After the PHP receives a report, which can be submitted anonymously, a thorough assessment is performed. If physician impairment is confirmed, management options are offered; the PHP is not obliged to notify the state medical board about the physician's condition if they voluntarily accept treatment. However, if the physician refuses treatment, the PHP will report the physician's condition to the state medical board, which may lead to an involuntary referral for treatment and disciplinary actions. After treatment, the PHP monitors the physician with regular assessments and/or laboratory tests for 1–5 years depending on the underlying condition.

answers.content: Contact the state medical licensing board
answers.explanation_why: The state medical licensing board should be the first institution contacted in cases of gross misconduct by health care professionals (e.g., sexual harassment of colleagues or patients, inappropriate prescription of controlled substances, fraud). Health care professionals reported to the state medical board may face disciplinary measures and/or have their medical license suspended/revoked. The behavior observed by the resident does not constitute gross misconduct, so it would be more appropriate to first contact another supervisory entity.

answers.content: Confront the colleague directly about his behavior
answers.explanation_why: Confronting the colleague directly may lead to a change in his behavior. However, individuals with substance use disorders are often in denial and may be resistant to interventions from colleagues. At this time, it is more appropriate to contact a supervisory entity; doing so will potentially be more beneficial both to patients and to the physician himself.
