question_text: Three days after an elective total knee replacement surgery for severe osteoarthritis, a hospitalized 66-year-old woman has difficulties sleeping because of knee pain. The physician on call for the night shift enters an order for ketorolac in the patient's electronic health record. Two hours later, a nurse notifies the physician that the drug was mistakenly administered to a patient in the room next door. The physician reviews the electronic records and notices that he had inadvertently entered the order for the wrong patient. The patient to whom ketorolac was administered feels “fine” and does not develop any side effects or require a prolonged hospital stay. Which of the following terms best describes the physician's action?
content_preview: Three days after an elective total knee replacement surgery for severe osteoarthritis, a hospitalized 66-year-old woman has difficulties sleeping because of knee pain. The physician on call for the night shift enters an order for ketorolac in the patient's electronic health record. Two hours later, a nurse notifies the physician that the drug was mistakenly administered to a patient in the room next door. The physician reviews the electronic records and notices that he had inadvertently entered the order for the wrong patient. The patient to whom ketorolac was administered feels “fine” and does not develop any side effects or require a prolonged hospital stay. Which of the following terms best describes the physician's action?
hint: The physician's actions constitute a medical error even though no harm occurred from administering ketorolac.
learning_objective: Recognize a sharp end error (active error).

answers.content: Latent error
answers.explanation_why: Latent errors (blunt end errors) remain unnoticed, have delayed impacts, and are the result of system design or organizational failures. Latent errors are often the underlying cause of the type of event that occurred in this scenario, but this physician's action did not remain unnoticed and had an immediate impact, so it was not a latent error.

answers.content: Ameliorable adverse event
answers.explanation_why: The patient did not experience any harm (e.g., prolonged hospital stay, side effects) from the administration of ketorolac, so neither the term adverse event nor its descriptors (e.g., nonpreventable, ameliorable, preventable) apply to the physician's action. The term preventable adverse event would apply if the patient had experienced harm from the inadvertent administration of ketorolac.

answers.content: Alert fatigue
answers.explanation_why: Alert fatigue refers to the phenomenon in which health care providers become desensitized to alarms or alerts that occur excessively or inappropriately and subsequently ignore or fail to respond appropriately to the alarm/alert. In this scenario, the physician did not ignore or miss an alarm or alert.

answers.content: Medical malpractice
answers.explanation_why: Medical malpractice, which is legally determined in a court of law, occurs when the following four criteria are met: A patient-physician relationship exists (duty), the physician acted negligently (dereliction of duty), the patient suffered harm (damages), and the patient's harm was the result of the physician's negligence (direct causation). In this case, only the first two of the four criteria are met (i.e., duty and dereliction of duty).

answers.content: Sharp end error
answers.explanation_why:
This physician has committed an active error (sharp end error) by ordering the drug for the wrong patient. Active errors (sharp end errors) occur at the level of contact between the healthcare provider and aspects of the health care system (e.g., patient, health records), are generally readily apparent, and usually have an immediate impact. Skills-based errors such as a slip (which occurred in this scenario) and a lapse are the most common types of active errors. This class of active errors can be prevented by implementing standardized protocols (e.g., implementing a SAFER checklist), organizational changes that minimize stress and fatigue (e.g., having float staff), and implementing forcing functions that minimize distractions (e.g., computerized provider order entry systems that allow only one electronic health record to be open at a time and medication orders to be entered only in a designated distraction-free zone). Such measures would simultaneously address the underlying latent errors that predispose to active errors.

Other terms that are applicable to describe the physician's action in this scenario are medication error (specifically at the stages of ordering and transcribing), patient identification error, near miss, medical negligence, and a nonreviewable sentinel event. A near miss is an error that exposes the patient to potential harm but does not do so because of either a timely intervention (e.g., the nurse identifies that a doctor's order is for the wrong patient) or luck (as in this case, in which the patient did not experience any adverse effect from ketorolac). Any intervention on a wrong patient is a sentinel event, which necessitates a root cause analysis.

See "Overview of medical error types" table.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, carotid artery stenosis, vascular dementia, and recurrent episodes of transient visual loss is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. Duplex ultrasonography and CT angiography of the carotid arteries had shown an 80% stenosis on the right and 50% stenosis on the left. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient records as “CEA right.” The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks “X” on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, carotid artery stenosis, vascular dementia, and recurrent episodes of transient visual loss is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. Duplex ultrasonography and CT angiography of the carotid arteries had shown an 80% stenosis on the right and 50% stenosis on the left. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient records as “CEA right.” The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks “X” on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?
hint: The Universal Protocol should be followed to prevent never events such as wrong-site surgery. This protocol consists of a series of steps based on the human factors engineering strategy of redundancy and standardization and should be performed before invasive medical procedures. In this scenario, the surgeon did not follow the protocol for one of these steps correctly and a subsequent step was missed entirely. If this subsequent step had been performed, it could have reduced the likelihood of the error occurring by acting as an additional safety measure (i.e., a Swiss cheese model).
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery to prevent wrong-site surgery.

answers.content: Performing surgical site marking in the operating room
answers.explanation_why: It is generally recommended that surgical site marking be performed in the preoperative area, where there are fewer distractions compared to the operating room. Marking may be performed by the attending surgeon after verbal confirmation from the patient, although it is acceptable to delegate to another person who will also be present during the procedure (e.g., the surgical intern in this scenario), or by the patient directly in front of the surgeon, but the site marking protocol should be standardized for each institution.

answers.content: Providing the patient with a radiofrequency identification wrist band
answers.explanation_why: Radiofrequency identification wrist bands can be used to verify a patient's identity and prevent errors caused by patient misidentification (e.g., wrong patient surgery). However, they are not typically used to identify surgical sites and it is unlikely that they would have prevented this patient's wrong-site surgery.

answers.content: Avoiding the use of abbreviations in patient records
answers.explanation_why: The use of nonstandardized abbreviations in documentation should be avoided to minimize errors. However, in this scenario, the procedure was documented as “CEA right” and correctly identified the laterality of the procedure.

answers.content: Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery
Using adhesive tape for surgical site marking
answers.explanation_why: The Joint Commission recommends making permanent surgical site markings to ensure that they are still visible following surgical preparation (e.g., antiseptic skin preparation and draping). Therefore, adhesive tape is not recommended because it can easily be rubbed off or transferred to a different site, which can result in wrong-site surgery.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He has schizophrenia and advanced metastatic lung cancer. At a visit 3 weeks ago, the patient reported severe weight loss and loss of appetite. The physician recommended palliative percutaneous gastrostomy and explained the procedure as well as its benefits and possible complications. At the time, the patient objected to the procedure, stating that he did not wish to undergo any surgical procedures or life-prolonging interventions, including resuscitation. He designated his brother as the medical power of attorney. Current medications include quetiapine, hydromorphone-acetaminophen, and prednisolone. The patient appears cachectic and ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m^2. He is alert and fully oriented. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 23/30. He has a flat affect. He denies auditory, visual, and tactile hallucinations. At the current visit, the patient appears to have changed his mind and wishes to undergo the procedure. His brother is present during the consultation and strongly disagrees with the patient's choice. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. He has schizophrenia and advanced metastatic lung cancer. At a visit 3 weeks ago, the patient reported severe weight loss and loss of appetite. The physician recommended palliative percutaneous gastrostomy and explained the procedure as well as its benefits and possible complications. At the time, the patient objected to the procedure, stating that he did not wish to undergo any surgical procedures or life-prolonging interventions, including resuscitation. He designated his brother as the medical power of attorney. Current medications include quetiapine, hydromorphone-acetaminophen, and prednisolone. The patient appears cachectic and ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. He is alert and fully oriented. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 23/30. He has a flat affect. He denies auditory, visual, and tactile hallucinations. At the current visit, the patient appears to have changed his mind and wishes to undergo the procedure. His brother is present during the consultation and strongly disagrees with the patient's choice. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
hint: This patient wants to undergo an invasive surgical procedure with potential complications. It is important to reassess his decision-making capacity, especially because of his risk factors for impaired cognition.
learning_objective: Recognize the need to reassess decision-making capacity in patients with cognitive impairment and schizophrenia, and choose the appropriate response to confirm their understanding.

answers.content: "I know that you initially decided against the procedure. Are you sure that you want a gastrostomy?"
answers.explanation_why: Although the first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening (in keeping with the PEARLS model), it is followed by a close-ended question (i.e., the patient may respond with only a "yes" or "no”), which does not help to assess his decision-making capacity.

answers.content: "This must have been a difficult decision for you. Would you allow me to perform a preoperative assessment if this is your final choice?"
answers.explanation_why: This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, performing a preoperative examination is premature at this time because the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

answers.content: "I see that you have changed your mind. Could you explain to me in your own words what you understand about gastrostomy?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient's sudden change in the decision to undergo an invasive surgical procedure, in combination with mildly impaired cognition (Mini-Mental State Examination score of 23/30) and features of schizophrenia (e.g., flat affect), should prompt a reassessment of his decision-making capacity. The first part of this statement acknowledges the patient's wish via active listening, in keeping with the PEARLS model. The second part helps to assess his decision-making capacity, which includes evaluation of the patient's understanding of the situation and ability to use information to make a choice. Though this patient has articulated a choice, it is not yet clear if he is able to assimilate and process the potential outcomes of the proposed procedure, despite the physician's previous explanations. Standardized instruments, such as the MacArthur Competence Assessment Tool, are used to evaluate capacity and legal competence and involve a semi-structured interview with open-ended questions to explore the patient's reasoning.

answers.content: "Your brother seems to disagree with your choice. Could you talk to him first?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient has named his brother the medical power of attorney (POA), and it is reasonable for him to discuss his condition and preferences with his brother. The POA is tasked with making decisions for the patient if the patient lacks decision-making capacity. In this scenario, the patient's decision-making capacity has not yet been assessed.

answers.content: "This must be a difficult decision to make. Would you like to talk to another physician?"
answers.explanation_why: This statement acknowledges the patient's feelings in an empathetic manner, in keeping with the PEARLS model. However, referring this patient to another physician is not medically indicated at this time, and the patient has not requested to speak with another physician.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 0, at 30 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Prenatal care for the current pregnancy was initiated late and she has missed several prenatal visits. She is not adherent to the micronutrient supplementation prescribed by the physician. She has a history of 3 medical abortions. Her medical history is remarkable for several visits to the emergency department over the past 5 years for nonspecific complaints. She is usually accompanied by her husband but has come in alone today. She appears anxious, has a tearful affect, and avoids eye contact. She denies any suicidal ideation. Physical examination shows multiple bruises of different ages on her forearms. When asked about the findings, the patient replies that she bruises easily. The remainder of the examination and the laboratory study results, including a complete blood count and coagulation studies, show no abnormalities. When asked if she feels safe in her relationship, the patient responds, “We have had our difficulties, like anyone, but my husband is a good man.” In addition to counseling and psychological support, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 0, at 30 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Prenatal care for the current pregnancy was initiated late and she has missed several prenatal visits. She is not adherent to the micronutrient supplementation prescribed by the physician. She has a history of 3 medical abortions. Her medical history is remarkable for several visits to the emergency department over the past 5 years for nonspecific complaints. She is usually accompanied by her husband but has come in alone today. She appears anxious, has a tearful affect, and avoids eye contact. She denies any suicidal ideation. Physical examination shows multiple bruises of different ages on her forearms. When asked about the findings, the patient replies that she bruises easily. The remainder of the examination and the laboratory study results, including a complete blood count and coagulation studies, show no abnormalities. When asked if she feels safe in her relationship, the patient responds, “We have had our difficulties, like anyone, but my husband is a good man.” In addition to counseling and psychological support, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: Late initiation of prenatal care, missed appointments, medication nonadherence, multiple abortions, injuries of different ages, and frequent visits to the emergency department should raise suspicion for intimate partner violence (IPV), which often becomes more severe during pregnancy and the postpartum period.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of intimate partner violence, and choose the appropriate resources to offer the patient.

answers.content: Inquire about access to a shelter
answers.explanation_why:
Individuals experiencing IPV are at high risk of health impairment (e.g., injury, preterm birth, death) and should be provided with information about in-house and community resources (e.g., shelters). Risk factors for escalation should be evaluated (e.g., partner being abusive during pregnancy, victim attempting to leave their partner) and a safety plan should be established with the patient before they leave the office. This plan typically includes advising the patient to prepare an emergency kit that contains important items (e.g., documents, money), which should be stored outside the home, defining a place to go to in case of an emergency (e.g., a shelter), setting up an alarm signal for contact persons (e.g., neighbors) to call emergency services, and advising the patient to avoid areas of increased risk at home in times of escalating violence (e.g., the kitchen, where knives are stored).

Screening for IPV is recommended in all women of reproductive age. If the partner is present during the patient interview, it is important to first separate the patient from the partner before addressing suspected IPV as confrontation in front of the partner can endanger the patient. Requirements for reporting IPV vary by state. Reporting IPV to law enforcement is mandatory in most states if there is evidence of weapon injury or imminent danger. If there is no such evidence, patient consent is necessary before reporting the case to authorities. If children are involved, reporting to child protective services is often mandatory. If the patient is an at-risk adult, reporting to adult protective services may be required.

answers.content: Encourage the patient to leave their partner
answers.explanation_why: Patients with suspected IPV should generally not be encouraged to leave their partners. Many patients are not ready to leave their partners because of financial or family dependencies, feelings of guilt, or fear of retaliation. Pressuring the patient to leave their partner may weaken the patient-physician relationship. If a patient discloses abuse by a partner, a different action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Contact Adult Protective Services
answers.explanation_why: Reporting abuse to Adult Protective Services is mandatory in most states in cases of abuse of vulnerable adults (e.g., disabled individuals, elderly individuals). In cases of IPV affecting adults who are not considered vulnerable, reporting regulations vary between states. If there is evidence or threat of injury from a weapon, law enforcement must be notified in most states. This patient, however, shows no evidence of injury from a weapon. Furthermore, pregnant women have full decision-making capacity and patient consent is required to report cases like this one if there is no evidence of imminent danger. Another step is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Revisit the topic of intimate partner violence at the next visit
answers.explanation_why: Prenatal care provides an opportunity for close follow-up of IPV and for assuring ongoing support by the provider. However, because this patient has already missed several prenatal appointments and had several visits to the emergency department, IPV should be addressed immediately. To best protect the safety of the patient and her unborn child, a different action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Admit the patient involuntarily
answers.explanation_why: Involuntary admission may become necessary in patients with severe psychiatric disorders who require medical treatment, have signs of grave disability (e.g., unable to maintain sufficient food, clothing, or shelter), or are a danger to themselves or others. Since this patient shows no evidence of a mental illness that would endanger herself or others, another step is more appropriate at this time.

question_text: A 5-day-old breast-fed male newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin. He was born at term following a vaginal delivery at home. The mother states that, initially, the newborn fed well every 2–3 hours but developed poor feeding and irritability over the past 24 hours. The mother received no prenatal care during her pregnancy. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 35^th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. His serum unconjugated bilirubin concentration is 31.5 mg/dL. The physician explains to the parents that the newborn must receive an exchange transfusion and phototherapy. The parents refuse to consent to the treatment and request immediate discharge, stating that they want to try "natural” treatment options such as ginger tea and sunbathing. Despite counseling about the consequences of not treating the child, the parents do not change their decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 5-day-old breast-fed male newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin. He was born at term following a vaginal delivery at home. The mother states that, initially, the newborn fed well every 2–3 hours but developed poor feeding and irritability over the past 24 hours. The mother received no prenatal care during her pregnancy. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 35th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. His serum unconjugated bilirubin concentration is 31.5 mg/dL. The physician explains to the parents that the newborn must receive an exchange transfusion and phototherapy. The parents refuse to consent to the treatment and request immediate discharge, stating that they want to try "natural” treatment options such as ginger tea and sunbathing. Despite counseling about the consequences of not treating the child, the parents do not change their decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This newborn's severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (> 30 mg/dL) puts him at increased risk of bilirubin encephalopathy (i.e., kernicterus), which leads to permanent neurological damage and potentially death.
learning_objective: Recognize when to initiate treatment in a pediatric emergency without parental consent.

answers.content: Seek a court order to override the parents' decision
answers.explanation_why: Seeking a court order to override parental refusal of treatment is appropriate for medical conditions that potentially threaten the child's life or limb but do not require immediate treatment (e.g., early-stage cancer). However, this newborn has a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention, and a court order would take some time to procure.

answers.content: Admit the patient and initiate appropriate treatment
answers.explanation_why: Although parental consent is usually required before minors (children < 18 years of age in most US states) receive medical care, it does not apply in emergency situations in which there is a legal obligation to treat in order to save a child's life or limb. Since severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia has a very high risk of permanent brain damage and death, it is a life-threatening medical emergency and immediate therapy is necessary. If the medical condition threatens the child's life or limb and the effective treatment can be delayed for a short while (e.g., early-stage cancer), a court order should be obtained if parents refuse the treatment, assuming all other measures to convince the parents have failed. Parental refusal to consent to therapy is legally permitted when there is no risk of serious harm to the minor (e.g., for most vaccination refusals) or when the minor has a terminal condition that does not have any effective treatment (e.g., advanced metastatic cancer, certain high-grade brain tumors).

answers.content: Discharge the patient and notify child protective services
answers.explanation_why: Physicians are obligated to immediately file a report with child protective services (CPS) in the case of suspected child neglect or abuse. Although withholding treatment for life-threatening conditions, as the parents are doing here, can be counted as neglect, notifying CPS would not be the most appropriate initial action by the physician.

answers.content: Discharge the patient after the parents sign an "against medical advice" form
answers.explanation_why: Discharging a patient who is a minor against medical advice is appropriate if there is no risk of serious harm to the patient (e.g., most cases of vaccination refusal or refusal of palliative treatment in a terminally ill minor). However, this newborn's condition is life-threatening and urgent intervention is required.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after a sexual assault during which she was penetrated vaginally. After the assailant left, the patient immediately drove to the hospital. She did not call the police or her family because she felt too embarrassed. Her medical and family history are unremarkable. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears tearful and startles when the door to the examination room is slammed shut. She is fully oriented and gives consent to proceed with physical examination and documentation of findings in the presence of a chaperone. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 126/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several bruises and abrasions on her upper arms and neck. Pelvic examination shows swelling and erythema of the vulva and vagina. There are multiple abrasions of the labia minora and majora with superficial bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The physician orders vaginal specimen nucleic acid amplification tests for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas, and serum testing for HIV, hepatitis B, and syphilis. The patient receives psychological counseling, and with her consent, the appropriate legal authorities are notified about the incident. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after a sexual assault during which she was penetrated vaginally. After the assailant left, the patient immediately drove to the hospital. She did not call the police or her family because she felt too embarrassed. Her medical and family history are unremarkable. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears tearful and startles when the door to the examination room is slammed shut. She is fully oriented and gives consent to proceed with physical examination and documentation of findings in the presence of a chaperone. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 126/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several bruises and abrasions on her upper arms and neck. Pelvic examination shows swelling and erythema of the vulva and vagina. There are multiple abrasions of the labia minora and majora with superficial bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The physician orders vaginal specimen nucleic acid amplification tests for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas, and serum testing for HIV, hepatitis B, and syphilis. The patient receives psychological counseling, and with her consent, the appropriate legal authorities are notified about the incident. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Individuals who have experienced sexual assault require active management during their initial presentation to decrease the risk of developing certain diseases.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate prophylactic antibiotics for sexual assault victims.

answers.content: Administer mifepristone and misoprostol 24 hours apart
answers.explanation_why: Emergency contraception should be offered to all female patients of reproductive age who have experienced sexual assault. However, the combination of an oral progesterone antagonist (e.g., mifepristone) with a prostaglandin analog (e.g., misoprostol) administered 24–48 hours apart is used for elective abortion rather than emergency contraception. Oral emergency contraception medication (i.e., ulipristal acetate, levonorgestrel, Yuzpe regimen) and intrauterine devices are both effective options for emergency contraception. Although IUDs have the highest reported efficacy in emergency contraception, the insertion of an IUD may increase distress in an individual who has experienced sexual assault.

answers.content: Prescribe tenofovir and abacavir
answers.explanation_why: HIV postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be offered to all individuals who present within 72 hours of experiencing a sexual assault involving vaginal penetration. Treatment usually includes a three-drug regimen of tenofovir, emtricitabine, and an integrase inhibitor (e.g., raltegravir, dolutegravir). Although two-drug regimens can be considered when there are concerns about cost or potential toxicity, three-drug regimens are more effective and less likely to result in resistance. Additionally, abacavir is not recommended in any PEP regimen because initial screening for the presence of HLA-B*57:01 is required and would therefore delay therapy.

answers.content: Administer HPV vaccine
answers.explanation_why: HPV vaccination is recommended in all women aged between 9–26 years who have experienced a sexual assault. This patient is 30 years of age and does not require an HPV vaccine at this time. Although HPV catch-up vaccination may be considered in women aged 27–45 years with an unknown HPV immunization status, its benefit in this age group is minimal. A different intervention is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin
answers.explanation_why: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) can be considered for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals who have experienced a sexual assault if the patient is not vaccinated and the perpetrator's HBsAg is positive. Fully vaccinated patients do not require HBIG regardless of the perpetrator's HBsAg status (see “HBV PEP following nonoccupational exposure” table).

answers.content: Prescribe ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole
answers.explanation_why: Empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole is indicated for sexually transmitted infection prophylaxis against gonorrhea, chlamydia, and trichomonas in all adults (trichomoniasis prophylaxis only in women) who have experienced a sexual assault. Because many patients who have experienced sexual assault do not return for a follow-up visit, empiric antibiotic therapy should be given at their initial presentation. Patients who do not receive empiric antibiotic therapy should repeat STI screening 1–2 weeks later because initial results are usually negative in previously uninfected patients. Other recommended interventions at the initial presentation include emergency contraception, HIV postexposure prophylaxis, and hepatitis B postexposure prophylaxis depending on the patient's profile (e.g., immunization status, serum testing results). Prophylaxis against herpes simplex virus is not recommended because there is insufficient evidence to support its effectiveness.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after having fallen from the balcony of his fifth-floor apartment. Emergency medical technicians arrived at the scene of injury 10 minutes after the fall and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) en route to the hospital. On arrival, he is unconscious and has a Glasgow coma score of 3. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F) and he has nonpalpable pulses with asystole on ECG. CPR is continued and the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Chest auscultation discloses clear lung fields with bilateral air entry and absent heart sounds. Point of care ultrasound shows visible sliding of the pleura and no cardiac wall motion. There is no evidence of fluid in the pericardium, ventricular dilation, or inferior vena cava collapse. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen shows a pH of 7.36 and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Despite continuing CPR for another 20 minutes, the ECG recordings persistently show asystole. The pupils are 9 mm and nonreactive to light. End-tidal carbon dioxide is 8 mm Hg (N = 35–45) and serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Two emergency medicine residents in their first postgraduate year ask the attending physician if they can practice femoral vein catheterization and scalpel cricothyroidotomy on the patient. There are no advance directives or emergency medical contacts in the patient's electronic health record. At this time, which of the following is the most appropriate instruction by the attending physician to the team treating the patient?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after having fallen from the balcony of his fifth-floor apartment. Emergency medical technicians arrived at the scene of injury 10 minutes after the fall and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) en route to the hospital. On arrival, he is unconscious and has a Glasgow coma score of 3. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F) and he has nonpalpable pulses with asystole on ECG. CPR is continued and the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Chest auscultation discloses clear lung fields with bilateral air entry and absent heart sounds. Point of care ultrasound shows visible sliding of the pleura and no cardiac wall motion. There is no evidence of fluid in the pericardium, ventricular dilation, or inferior vena cava collapse. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen shows a pH of 7.36 and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Despite continuing CPR for another 20 minutes, the ECG recordings persistently show asystole. The pupils are 9 mm and nonreactive to light. End-tidal carbon dioxide is 8 mm Hg (N = 35–45) and serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Two emergency medicine residents in their first postgraduate year ask the attending physician if they can practice femoral vein catheterization and scalpel cricothyroidotomy on the patient. There are no advance directives or emergency medical contacts in the patient's electronic health record. At this time, which of the following is the most appropriate instruction by the attending physician to the team treating the patient?
hint: In this patient, reversible causes of posttraumatic cardiac arrest (e.g., tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, exsanguination, asphyxiation) have been excluded. Before making a decision, the attending physician must consider the following scenario-specific features: high-energy trauma, out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, late initiation of CPR, a cumulative CPR time > 30 minutes without return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) or a rhythm change at any point, end-tidal CO_2  < 10 mm Hg, and an examination finding suggestive of brainstem areflexia.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical considerations in pronouncing death and obtaining consent for postmortem procedures.

answers.content: Continue CPR and attempt to contact the patient's family
answers.explanation_why: When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, so it is appropriate to contact this patient's family. However, considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile.

answers.content: Pronounce death and attempt to contact the patient's family
answers.explanation_why:
Although no single factor or specific combination of factors can clearly predict the outcome of resuscitative efforts in a hospital setting, it is appropriate to pronounce death in this patient when all the scenario-specific features are taken into account (e.g., effective CPR for > 30 minutes without ROSC, no shockable rhythm). Performing procedures on newly deceased patients can provide valuable hands-on training for inexperienced health care providers. However, consent from the next of kin is required for each procedure if the deceased's preferences are not known. According to the Uniform Anatomical Gifts Act, in the absence of an advance directive or emergency medical contacts in the patient's records, emergency physicians and medical technicians are allowed to search through the patient's belongings and may share their personal information (e.g., social security number) with authorities to identify them.

If the next of kin cannot be located within a reasonable time frame, it is ethically inappropriate to use the body of a deceased patient for training purposes, regardless of the degree of invasiveness of the procedure. If consent is obtained, the training procedures should be organized systematically and conducted under close supervision while ensuring a respectful environment for the deceased and their family.

answers.content: Pronounce death and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision
answers.explanation_why: Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, it is appropriate to pronounce this patient dead. However, when the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure is performed, regardless of the level of supervision.

answers.content: Pronounce death and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
answers.explanation_why: Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, it is appropriate to pronounce this patient dead. However, when the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure is performed, regardless of the degree of invasiveness or level of supervision.

question_text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician as a new patient and requests a whole-body CT scan for cancer screening because she can feel that “there is something in her body.” Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She has had several jobs over the past 10 years but is currently unemployed and has Medicaid insurance. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient explains that she has seen several physicians in the past, but all of them refused to order the requested test for her. She says, “You seem wonderful, unlike my previous physicians. They were all incompetent. I even filed a lawsuit against one of them!” On exploring the patient's fear of cancer and the reasons for her inquiry, she reports that she saw an online direct-to-consumer advertisement about whole-body CT scans. The physician explains when whole-body CT scans are performed and why the test is not indicated in her case. The patient becomes agitated and insists that the physician order the test. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician as a new patient and requests a whole-body CT scan for cancer screening because she can feel that “there is something in her body.” Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She has had several jobs over the past 10 years but is currently unemployed and has Medicaid insurance. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient explains that she has seen several physicians in the past, but all of them refused to order the requested test for her. She says, “You seem wonderful, unlike my previous physicians. They were all incompetent. I even filed a lawsuit against one of them!” On exploring the patient's fear of cancer and the reasons for her inquiry, she reports that she saw an online direct-to-consumer advertisement about whole-body CT scans. The physician explains when whole-body CT scans are performed and why the test is not indicated in her case. The patient becomes agitated and insists that the physician order the test. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request?
hint: This patient is asking for a cancer screening test that is not scientifically validated and not covered by her medical insurance. The physician should use a directive counseling approach when responding to her request.
learning_objective: Recognize when to reject a patient's request for nonindicated tests based on beneficence and nonmaleficence.

answers.content: "I understand that you are concerned about having cancer. I can order the test if you are willing to sign an against-medical-advice form."
answers.explanation_why: This response shows empathy and acknowledges the patient's concerns, which helps to build a trusting patient-physician relationship. However, regardless of whether the patient signs an against-medical-advice form, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

answers.content: "A whole-body CT scan is associated with high levels of radiation exposure. I would instead recommend an MRI scan, which is a safer alternative."
answers.explanation_why: This response relies on the principle of shared-decision making, according to which patients and physicians decide on the best diagnostic and/or treatment option together. Although an MRI is not associated with radiation exposure and therefore has fewer potential risks than a CT scan, neither a CT scan nor an MRI is indicated in this case.

answers.content: "There is no indication that you might benefit from this test. I cannot in good conscience order the test for you at this time."
answers.explanation_why:
This response firmly yet politely rejects the patient's request. When evaluating a patient's demand for nonindicated care, physicians need to balance the core ethical principles. The ethical principle of patient autonomy, according to which a physician only assists in making decisions corresponding to the patient's personal values, is overruled in favor of beneficence and nonmaleficence in this directive counseling approach. Since there is no evidence that the possible benefits of whole-body CT scanning of asymptomatic individuals (e.g., to relieve the fear of cancer) outweigh the potential harm (e.g., radiation exposure, potential detection of ill-defined abnormalities requiring follow-up testing and interventions), the physician is acting in the patient's best interest (beneficence) and preventing harm (nonmaleficence). Moreover, denying nonindicated investigations and interventions also helps to ensure more equitable care. Finally, it is important for the physician to emphasize that the test is currently not indicated; it might be indicated in the future.

The patient's behavior in this scenario resembles splitting, a psychological defense mechanism characteristic of borderline personality disorder. Splitting involves separating experiences or people into all-good and all-bad, such as this patient's negative description of her past physicians. To minimize the effects of splitting, health care providers should collaborate toward common management goals, communicate regularly, and clarify their roles in patient care.

answers.content: "Unfortunately, your health insurance plan will not cover this test. Would you be willing to pay for it yourself?"
answers.explanation_why: Patients may require a test or treatment not covered by their insurance, in which case they should be informed about the option of paying for the service out of pocket. However, regardless of whether it is covered by her insurance, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

answers.content: "I am sorry that there is nothing I can do for you at this point. If you insist on having the test, I think it would be best to see another physician."
answers.explanation_why: While physicians should always inform patients of their right to seek an additional medical opinion, it is not appropriate to threaten to end the patient-physician relationship because the patient insists on having a nonindicated test. Also, sending the patient to another physician will not solve the problem. Denying the request for a nonindicated screening test is the correct action, which is why the physician should refrain from apologizing. Finally, it is not true that the physician cannot do anything at this point, when the patient could be counseled on other aspects of health maintenance.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office with his wife because of a 1-week history of left-sided scrotal swelling. He is seen by a female physician. He has no scrotal pain or penile discharge. He has no history of any trauma to the region. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is sexually active with his wife and uses condoms consistently. Prior to the examination, he asks his wife to step outside the room. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. During the genitourinary examination, the patient says, “That feels good! I wouldn't mind if you continued.” In addition to telling the patient that the comment is inappropriate, which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action by the physician?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the office with his wife because of a 1-week history of left-sided scrotal swelling. He is seen by a female physician. He has no scrotal pain or penile discharge. He has no history of any trauma to the region. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is sexually active with his wife and uses condoms consistently. Prior to the examination, he asks his wife to step outside the room. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. During the genitourinary examination, the patient says, “That feels good! I wouldn't mind if you continued.” In addition to telling the patient that the comment is inappropriate, which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action by the physician?
hint: Although health care professionals should address inappropriate patient behavior (e.g., discrimination, sexist remarks), it should not be at the expense of the primary professional obligation to the patient.
learning_objective: Recognize inappropriate patient behavior, and choose the appropriate response to maintain a professional environment.

answers.content: Report the incident to law enforcement authorities
answers.explanation_why: Inappropriate comments from patients are not an indication for notifying law enforcement authorities. Situations in which a physician must provide law enforcement authorities with patient information include suspected cases of injury caused by a criminal act and the abuse of children, elderly people, or people with disabilities.

answers.content: Transfer the care of the patient to a male physician
answers.explanation_why: Transferring the care of the patient to a male physician does not address this patient's inappropriate behavior. While it may be reasonable for the original physician to terminate the patient-physician relationship and transfer the patient's care if he continues to behave inappropriately, a more appropriate initial step is to attempt to address the behavior itself.

answers.content: Call the patient's partner back into the room
answers.explanation_why: As part of the patient-physician relationship, physicians should try to create a comfortable environment in order to build trust and provide optimal care for their patients. This patient has requested that his wife is not present during the examination, and his request should be respected in order to maintain trust.

answers.content: Request the presence of a chaperone
answers.explanation_why: As part of the patient-physician relationship, physicians should try to create a comfortable environment in order to build trust and fulfill their duty to provide optimal care for their patients. Inappropriate patient behavior can make fulfilling this duty challenging and should be addressed directly. In this scenario, telling the patient that his comment is inappropriate in a polite and direct manner (so as to not undermine the therapeutic alliance) and requesting the presence of a medical chaperone (i.e., an authorized member of the care team, who can act as an impartial observer and witness) can help create an environment in which all parties feel comfortable and respected. Family members and other close contacts are not appropriate medical chaperones. Additional strategies to prevent inappropriate behavior include asking direct, close-ended questions and performing only medically necessary portions of the examination to minimize contact.

answers.content: Use humor to diffuse the situation
answers.explanation_why: Physicians may choose to use humor in the clinical setting to cultivate the patient-physician relationship. However, using humor to diffuse the situation in this scenario would downplay the seriousness of the patient's inappropriate behavior.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated in a rehabilitation facility, where he has been receiving physical therapy since undergoing total right knee replacement 18 months ago. The patient claims that he has been “feeling great for 6 months now” and does not understand why his primary care physician insists on referring him for more physical therapy sessions. The physician at the rehabilitation facility notices that the primary care physician who referred the patient happens to be the owner of the rehabilitation facility. The patient's referral notes list musculoskeletal symptoms that the patient denies having. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is evaluated in a rehabilitation facility, where he has been receiving physical therapy since undergoing total right knee replacement 18 months ago. The patient claims that he has been “feeling great for 6 months now” and does not understand why his primary care physician insists on referring him for more physical therapy sessions. The physician at the rehabilitation facility notices that the primary care physician who referred the patient happens to be the owner of the rehabilitation facility. The patient's referral notes list musculoskeletal symptoms that the patient denies having. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: The owner of the rehabilitation facility is suspected of engaging in self-referral (Stark law violation) and billing fraud, both of which are examples of professional misconduct.
learning_objective: Recognize professional misconduct, and choose the appropriate authority to report it.

answers.content: Record the incident in the Physician Quality Reporting System
answers.explanation_why: The Physician Quality Reporting System (PQRS) is used to monitor quality metrics of physicians and provides continuous feedback to physicians with the aim of improving the quality and cost-effectiveness of health care. This system is not used to report physician misconduct.

answers.content: Notify the rehabilitation facility's peer review body
answers.explanation_why: If a health care provider (HCP) suspected of misconduct is within the purview of the health care organization, the HCP may first be reported to an oversight authority within the organization (e.g., department chair, chief medical officer, peer review body). In this scenario, the owner of the rehabilitation facility, who is outside the purview of any oversight authority at the rehabilitation facility, is suspected of misconduct; a different regulatory authority must be informed.

answers.content: Contact the state medical licensing board
answers.explanation_why:
A suspected violation of medical licensing provisions should always be reported to an appropriate authority. A health care provider (HCP) who witnesses such a violation but fails to report it can be held liable for concealment. Suspected incidents of misconduct or incompetence can be reported initially to an oversight authority within the organization (e.g., department chair, chief medical officer, peer review body) if the HCP under suspicion is within the oversight authority's purview. The incident should be reported to the state medical licensing board (SMLB) if the HCP under suspicion is outside the oversight authority's purview (as in this scenario), the incident continues despite initial reporting, or, for any reason, the incident cannot be reported to an oversight authority. Complaints to the SMLB can be filed by anyone (e.g., patients, HCPs, other SMLBs), and, in some states, anonymously. Following a complaint to the SMLB, the licensee against whom the complaint is made receives a formal notification and is asked to make a statement and provide information to clarify the situation. If required, the SMLB can initiate formal hearings and/or initiate disciplinary actions (board orders).

In the case of billing fraud, the appropriate investigatory authority of the insurance provider (e.g., CMS office in cases of Medicaid or Medicare fraud) should also be informed. If the alleged misconduct potentially violates any criminal statutes, law enforcement authorities should also be informed. When a violation of a medical licensing provision is suspected to be due to physician impairment, it is appropriate to first inform the local Physician Health Program (PHP), which is supervised by the SMLB and can make recommendations to the SMLB if required.

answers.content: Disclose the incident to all patients referred by the owner
answers.explanation_why: Individuals who have been affected from self-referrals or billing fraud should be informed once the incident has been investigated and the misconduct has been confirmed. However, a physician who witnesses the suspected misconduct does not have the right to check the records of patients with whom the physician does not have a patient-physician relationship, since this would be a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Instead, the physician should report the incident to an appropriate body with investigatory authority that can determine whether multiple instances of self-referrals or billing fraud occurred.

answers.content: Report the incident to the local Physician Health Program
answers.explanation_why: The Physician Health Program (PHP) is responsible for preventing, detecting, and managing physician impairment due to mental health or substance use disorders and conditions that limit the physician's motor skills or cognitive capacity. This physician is suspected of misconduct, not impairment. Therefore, an organization other than the PHP should be informed.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation 12 hours before a scheduled cholecystectomy. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with cholelithiasis after recurrent episodes of biliary colic. Current medications include oral contraceptives and multivitamins. The physician obtains informed consent only for the cholecystectomy and the patient is brought to the operating room. After induction and anesthesia, the surgeon removes the gallbladder but also finds a 3-cm, ill-defined subcapsular mass in the right lobe of the liver. Results of a frozen section from the lesion are consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma, which will require additional surgery. The patient has no durable medical power of attorney. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation 12 hours before a scheduled cholecystectomy. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with cholelithiasis after recurrent episodes of biliary colic. Current medications include oral contraceptives and multivitamins. The physician obtains informed consent only for the cholecystectomy and the patient is brought to the operating room. After induction and anesthesia, the surgeon removes the gallbladder but also finds a 3-cm, ill-defined subcapsular mass in the right lobe of the liver. Results of a frozen section from the lesion are consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma, which will require additional surgery. The patient has no durable medical power of attorney. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has not given preoperative consent for liver surgery. In such cases, it is important to evaluate the life-threatening potential of findings, which will determine further management.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for informed consent for additional procedures discovered intraoperatively, and choose the appropriate next step when consent is not given.

answers.content: Proceed with additional surgery without obtaining consent
answers.explanation_why: Performing an additional surgical procedure without the patient's prior consent is only appropriate in emergency situations in which there is an immediate threat to the patient's life or health. Although the findings consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma are serious, they do not pose an immediate threat to this patient's life.

answers.content: Decrease the patient's sedation until she is able to provide consent
answers.explanation_why: Although decreasing the patient's sedation in order for her to provide consent for proceeding with surgery would avoid an additional surgery at a later point, it would also subject the patient to unnecessary pain and potential psychological trauma. Moreover, a patient regaining consciousness from sedation is unlikely to immediately have full decision-making capacity.

answers.content: Contact the patient's next of kin
answers.explanation_why: Obtaining consent from a surrogate decision-maker, such as the patient's next of kin, is appropriate for a patient without decision-making capacity who requires a nonemergency procedure (e.g., cancer surgery). This patient, however, does not lack decision-making capacity and will be capable of giving consent as soon as she regains consciousness.

answers.content: Close the patient and obtain consent for a second operation
answers.explanation_why: Informed consent is a fundamental legal concept that applies to all physicians in all fields of medicine. If an incidental finding during surgery does not require immediate action, performing an additional procedure without patient consent is unlawful. In this patient undergoing cholecystectomy, the surgeon incidentally discovers hepatocellular carcinoma that does not currently pose immediate life-threatening harm. Therefore, closing the patient, waking her up, and obtaining consent is the most appropriate next step. In situations in which there is a threat of immediate harm if the patient is not treated, the need for full informed consent is waived. If a patient lacks decision-making capacity (e.g., due to coma), consent for nonemergency procedures should be obtained from the patient's designated medical power of attorney or, if there is no such designated person, a next of kin.

answers.content: Schedule an emergency hospital ethics consultation
answers.explanation_why: Consulting the hospital ethics committee is appropriate for a patient without decision-making capacity who requires a nonemergency procedure (e.g., cancer surgery) and whose surrogate decision-maker is not available or is thought to be acting against the patient's preferences or best interest. This patient, however, does not lack decision-making capacity and will be capable of giving consent as soon as she regains consciousness.

question_text: A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated?
content_preview: A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated?
hint: A physician who is impaired (e.g., an intoxicated surgeon) has a higher risk of committing a medical error that causes injury to the patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the principle of nonmaleficence in patient care.

answers.content: Beneficence
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, beneficence refers to acting in the best interest of the patient (“do good”). Surgical management of appendicitis in this patient is in his best interest. However, the surgeon's intoxicated state impairs the safety of the procedure and puts the patient at risk of harm due to a medical error. While it is the intention of the surgeon to do good, the principle to “do no harm” would be violated if she continued with the procedure in her impaired state.

answers.content: Justice
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, justice refers to treating patients fairly and equitably, i.e., treatment is determined by the patient's specific medical needs (in contrast to treating all patients the same way). This patient needs an emergency appendectomy and is scheduled for this procedure, so the principle of justice is upheld.

answers.content: Autonomy
answers.explanation_why: In medical ethics, autonomy refers to a patient or guardian's right to make decisions about whether or not to undergo treatment. This patient is legally emancipated, retained full decision-making capacities at the time of the diagnosis, and a surgical resident obtained informed consent for the procedure. The principle of patient autonomy is therefore respected.

answers.content: Nonmaleficence
answers.explanation_why:
Nonmaleficence is the medical ethical principle of avoiding patient injury or suffering (i.e., “do no harm”). Most decisions in patient care require weighing the principle of nonmaleficence against the principle of beneficence (i.e., acting in the patient's best interest). In this scenario, the patient has an indication for an emergency appendectomy, and surgical management is in his best interest (principle of beneficence). However, the patient is at risk of serious harm due to physician impairment, and this risk cannot be outweighed by the benefits of having the procedure done by an impaired physician. The operating room staff needs to prevent the surgeon from performing the appendectomy and find a substitute surgeon.

In addition, the Physician Health Program (PHP) should be informed about the incident. The PHP will perform a thorough assessment of the physician and arrange appropriate management and support if an impairment is confirmed. Note that the PHP is not obliged to notify the state medical board if the physician accepts treatment of the impairing condition.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
hint: This patient's behavior and posture indicates a risk of impending violence. When confronted with an aggressive or violent patient, the health care provider (HCP)'s first priority is to ensure personal safety and attempt to deescalate the situation.
learning_objective: Recognize strategies for ensuring personal safety and deescalating aggressive behavior in patients.

answers.content: Use the additional personnel to set up a four-point restraint on the patient
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the use of force, such as physical restraints (e.g., a four-point restraint) or chemical restraints, should be a last resort.

answers.content: Stand between the patient and the ED exit and request that the patient take a sedative medication orally
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should position themself closer to the exit than the patient to ensure an escape route in case the aggressive behavior escalates. If a chemical restraint is indicated, it is also appropriate for the HCP to request that the patient voluntarily take the calming medication orally before considering use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation). However, the HCP should not block the exit by standing between the patient and the exit, because this action can be perceived as threatening and lead to escalation of the aggressive behavior. Moreover the HCP should attempt verbal deescalation before considering the use of a chemical restraint.

answers.content: Take turns speaking to the patient with another health care provider
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, it is important to have other HCPs nearby to provide assistance in case the aggressive behavior escalates. However, only one HCP should talk to the patient to avoid confusion and further escalation.

answers.content: Step two arm lengths away from the patient and offer the patient food and water
answers.explanation_why:
To ensure personal safety when dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should step two arm lengths away and position themselves closer to the exit (so that there is an escape route) without blocking the patient's view or access to the exit. The HCP should then attempt verbal deescalation. Offering comfort measures (e.g., food, water) is an appropriate initial step. During verbal deescalation, only one HCP should talk to the patient; the HCP should remain calm, maintain a neutral expression, respect the patient's personal space, and avoid gestures that can be perceived as threatening (e.g., sudden movement, staring back at the patient, expressing a condescending or commanding attitude). The HCP should acknowledge the patient's feelings, ask what the patient wants, and allow the patient to choose between different acceptable options (e.g., sitting down or lying down); doing so gives the patient a sense of control while also clarifying rules and limits (e.g., informing the patient that violent or abusive behavior will not be accepted). The HCP should listen actively, use short sentences and simple words, seek out points on which they and the patient can agree, and give the patient time to process information and respond.

If the patient continues to remain aggressive despite attempts at verbal deescalation, it is appropriate to ask the patient to voluntarily take a calming medication orally before considering use of force. The use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation) should only be considered if all other measures fail or if the patient is actively violent. Physical restraints and/or involuntary sedation should not be used as punishment and should be removed as soon as feasible.

answers.content: Sit next to the patient and maintain eye contact in silence until the patient calms down
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should maintain a safe distance to ensure personal safety and attempt to speak to the patient in a calm tone to deescalate the situation. The HCP should avoid maintaining eye contact because it can be perceived as a threatening gesture and lead to escalation of aggressive behavior by the patient.

question_text: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
content_preview: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
hint: Physician A's behavior violates the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical principles violated by physician misconduct.

answers.content: Malpractice
answers.explanation_why: Medical malpractice occurs when a healthcare provider violates professional standards through negligent conduct or acts of omission, resulting in patient harm. The elements of malpractice (i.e., the 4 Ds) are the duty to properly treat the patient, dereliction of that duty, damage to the patient, and direct cause of damage through medical negligence. Although Physician A neglected the duty to treat his patients, none have been directly damaged. Therefore, he did not commit malpractice and a different term describes his actions.

answers.content: Misconduct
answers.explanation_why: Physician misconduct is any behavior that goes against the ethical principles of medical practice. In this scenario, physician A leaves the hospital and puts patients at risk through his absence, which violates the principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence. This behavior is never acceptable regardless of whether it results in harm to a patient or incurs legal consequences. Misconduct can also occur outside the established physician-patient relationship and does not always constitute malpractice (e.g., research malfeasance, fraudulent advertising). Other examples of misconduct include bullying, making inappropriate comments and/or sexually harassing colleagues or patients, billing fraud, and receiving gifts from patients or pharmaceutical industry representatives. Colleagues who suspect a physician of misconduct should report their concerns to the state medical board, and, if the misconduct implies any legal liability, to the appropriate legal authorities.

answers.content: Slip
answers.explanation_why: Slip is an unintentional active error in the performance of a task that is caused by a lack of mindful attention (e.g., accidentally pushing the bolus button instead of giving the medication in infusion). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

answers.content: Mistake
answers.explanation_why: A mistake is a failed outcome resulting from an intentional action because of an error in execution and/or planning (e.g., making a misdiagnosis during an emergency and subsequently performing the wrong diagnostic test). Mistakes are more likely to occur while under time pressure, during multitasking and the execution of complex tasks, and when there is a lack of experience. Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

answers.content: Lapse
answers.explanation_why: A lapse is an unintentional active error caused by a lack of mindful attention and a fault in memory (e.g., forgetting about a patient's penicillin allergy and prescribing amoxicillin). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

question_text: An ophthalmological research group decides to design a randomized, nonblinded, controlled trial to investigate the effect of meditation on subretinal fluid volume in patients with central serous chorioretinopathy. A statistician performs a sample size calculation. Two hundred men between 30 and 50 years of age with central serous chorioretinopathy need to be recruited and randomized to receive either routine care or meditation training with routine care for 6 months. The primary endpoint of the trial is the decrease in subretinal fluid measured with optical coherence tomography after 2, 4, and 6 months. The study protocol is reviewed and approved by an institutional review board. An ophthalmologist unaffiliated with the research group learns about the planned study from an online registry of clinical trials for participant recruitment. She recommends lowering the inclusion criteria for participants to 25 years of age because she recently read an article on the increasing incidence of serous chorioretinopathy in younger men. The research group agrees and decides to adjust the study protocol accordingly. Before continuing with the recruitment of additional study participants, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the lead physician-investigator?

A statistician performs a sample size calculation.
