The primary endpoint of the trial is the decrease in subretinal fluid measured with optical coherence tomography after 2, 4, and 6 months. The study protocol is reviewed and approved by an institutional review board. An ophthalmologist unaffiliated with the research group learns about the planned study from an online registry of clinical trials for participant recruitment. She recommends lowering the inclusion criteria for participants to 25 years of age because she recently read an article on the increasing incidence of serous chorioretinopathy in younger men. The research group agrees and decides to adjust the study protocol accordingly. Before continuing with the recruitment of additional study participants, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the lead physician-investigator?
hint: A clinical trial involving human subjects needs to be reviewed and approved before initiating any research activity to ensure safety and compliance with medical ethics.
learning_objective: Recognize the need to submit protocol amendments to the Institutional Review Board.

answers.content: Include a secondary outcome measure in the informed consent form
answers.explanation_why: Changes in the recruitment protocol (e.g., inclusion or exclusion criteria) should be communicated to current and prospective participants and must be implemented in the informed consent form. However, secondary outcome measures are typically part of the study protocol rather than the informed consent form. Moreover, changes in the inclusion criteria do not automatically necessitate a change in the outcome measures and aim of the study.

answers.content: Disenroll participants who have already been recruited
answers.explanation_why: Participants who have already been recruited should be informed about the change in inclusion criteria and asked if they still want to participate in the trial. However, they do not need to be automatically disenrolled.

answers.content: No further action is required
answers.explanation_why: A research group may change study protocols during a trial for practical (e.g., personnel changes) and/or scientific reasons (e.g., changes in inclusion or exclusion criteria). To ensure safety, any changes to the protocol must be communicated to the relevant parties and approved by the appropriate organization.

answers.content: Submit a protocol amendment to the Institutional Review Board
answers.explanation_why:
Any changes to an approved research protocol (e.g., including a patient population that was previously excluded from the study) must be submitted to and evaluated by an institutional review board (IRB). An IRB is a committee responsible for conducting initial and ongoing reviews and providing oversight for research activities involving human subjects. Even minor changes, such as lowering the inclusion criteria for participants to 25 years of age, should be communicated to and approved by the IRB.

Human research that is performed or supported by a federal department or agency in the United States must be in accordance with the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects (i.e., the Common Rule). Examples of studies that do not require IRB review include service surveys, interviews about products or policies, educational tests, and secondary research involving publicly available identifiable private information (e.g., labor statistics).

answers.content: Consult the Office for Human Research Protections
answers.explanation_why: The Office for Human Research Protection (OHRP) oversees and provides guidance on biomedical and behavioral research involving human subjects. Reasons to consult the OHRP include risk to participants and noncompliance with the requirements of the institutional review board. Lowering the inclusion criteria to 25 years of age is not a reason to directly consult the OHRP.

question_text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unresponsive. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Temperature is 34.9°C (94.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg after intravenous administration of norepinephrine. Neurological examination on admission shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. A subsequent independent evaluation by another physician is concordant with these findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate action at this time?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unresponsive. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Temperature is 34.9°C (94.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg after intravenous administration of norepinephrine. Neurological examination on admission shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. A subsequent independent evaluation by another physician is concordant with these findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate action at this time?
hint: Coma and signs of brainstem areflexia (e.g., dilated, nonreactive pupils and absence of corneal, gag, and cough reflexes) along with radiological evidence of acute, severe damage to the CNS (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage) suggest brain death.
learning_objective: Choose the initial step in managing a potential brain death diagnosis.

answers.content: Perform an apnea test
answers.explanation_why: Apnea testing is an essential part of diagnosing brain death and is typically carried out after all other criteria (e.g., coma, brainstem areflexia) have been met. However, because certain confounding factors can lead to misdiagnosis of brain death, there are prerequisites for apnea testing.

answers.content: Discontinue norepinephrine and repeat tests
answers.explanation_why: Adequate cerebral perfusion, i.e. systolic blood pressure (SBP) > 100 mm Hg is required for the diagnosis of brain death. If SBP falls below 100 mm Hg, vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) should be administered. Discontinuing norepinephrine in this patient may lower SBP and impede clinical judgment.

answers.content: No further action is indicated
answers.explanation_why: In order to diagnose brain death, there must be evidence of a specific cause (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage), and neurological examination must confirm coma and brainstem areflexia. Although this patient meets these criteria, diagnosis of brain death also requires the absence of confounding factors, and the neurological examination should include apnea testing.

answers.content: Perform a somatosensory evoked potentials test
answers.explanation_why: Somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) are ancillary tests for brain death that are only indicated if clinical examination and/or apnea testing are inconclusive or if the patient is younger than one year of age. Ancillary testing is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Correct hypothermia
answers.explanation_why: Confounding factors may interfere with brain death assessment and should be corrected before diagnosis. Core body temperature must be > 36.0°C (> 96.8°F) for a minimum of 24 hours because hypothermia may impede neurological assessment and delay the increase in pCO_2 in apnea testing. Normothermia can be achieved by covering the patient with warming blankets and/or administering warm intravenous fluids. Other causes of impaired brain function, such as poisoning, drug intoxication, electrolyte imbalances, and hypotension as well as conditions that can mimic brain death (e.g., locked-in syndrome) should be ruled out and corrected if possible. Systolic blood pressure must be > 100 mm Hg, which may require the administration of vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine). If these prerequisites are met and patients still present with coma and brainstem areflexia, apnea testing can be performed for a definitive diagnosis of brain death.

question_text:
A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has osteoporosis treated with alendronate. She asks the physician if she could try nydronate because she recently saw an advertisement promoting it as a less expensive drug for treating osteoporosis. She would like to save money on her medication copayments and points out that a month's supply of nydronate costs 20% less than alendronate. While evaluating the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial assessing the effectiveness of nydronate compared to alendronate in individuals over 60 years of age. A total of 320 patients were enrolled and separated randomly into two groups. The results of the study after 2 years of follow-up show:

Outcomes
Alendronate
Nydronate
P value

Pathological fractures
16.3%
11.3%
.003

Osteonecrosis of the jaw
6.4%
2.4%
<.001

Hypocalcemia
8.4%
5.2%
.02

Gastric ulcers
29%
28%
.77

The physician finds out that nydronate is not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for any indication. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has osteoporosis treated with alendronate. She asks the physician if she could try nydronate because she recently saw an advertisement promoting it as a less expensive drug for treating osteoporosis. She would like to save money on her medication copayments and points out that a month's supply of nydronate costs 20% less than alendronate. While evaluating the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial assessing the effectiveness of nydronate compared to alendronate in individuals over 60 years of age. A total of 320 patients were enrolled and separated randomly into two groups. The results of the study after 2 years of follow-up show: Outcomes Alendronate Nydronate P value Pathological fractures 16.3% 11.3% .003 Osteonecrosis of the jaw 6.4% 2.4% <.001 Hypocalcemia 8.4% 5.2% .02 Gastric ulcers 29% 28% .77 The physician finds out that nydronate is not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for any indication. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action regarding prescription of non-FDA-approved drugs.

answers.content: Do not prescribe nydronate because it is not FDA-approved
answers.explanation_why:
The FDA reviews drugs for safety, quality, and efficacy for their intended use. Physicians should never prescribe drugs that are not FDA-approved. Although prescribing an unapproved drug is not illegal, a physician can be liable for medical malpractice if their patient develops side effects.

Off-label use, which is the use of an FDA-approved drug for an unapproved indication, is appropriate if supported by clinical practice guidelines. Examples of off-label use include prescribing SSRIs for premature ejaculation and letrozole for infertility treatment in polycystic ovarian syndrome.

answers.content: Prescribe nydronate on an off-label basis
answers.explanation_why: Off-label use is the use of an FDA-approved drug for an unapproved indication, population, form, or dosage. Because nydronate is not approved by the FDA for any indication, prescribing nydronate on an off-label basis is inappropriate.

answers.content: Prescribe nydronate because it is cheaper and more effective
answers.explanation_why: FDA-approved drugs may be more expensive than unapproved drugs because of market dynamics and costs incurred during drug development, and the clinical trial results suggest that nydronate is more effective (lower risk of pathological fractures) and safer (lower risk of osteonecrosis of the jaw and hypocalcemia) than alendronate in treating osteoporosis. However, it is inappropriate to prescribe a drug that is not FDA-approved based on results from a single clinical trial or just because it is cheaper. Cost should only be considered when choosing between FDA-approved drugs that are equally effective and safe to treat a patient's condition.

answers.content: File an orphan drug designation request with the FDA
answers.explanation_why: Orphan drug designation can fast-track FDA approval but only applies to drugs that treat rare diseases (defined by the FDA as affecting < 200,000 people in the US). Osteoporosis does not meet the criteria for orphan drug designation.

answers.content: File an expanded access request with the FDA
answers.explanation_why: Filing an expanded access request to use an unapproved drug outside of a clinical trial is possible, but expanded access permission is only given for a serious or immediately life-threatening illness that has no available alternative therapy. Osteoporosis does not meet the criteria for expanded access permission.

question_text:
A phase 2 multicenter, double-blind randomized superiority trial is performed to compare the efficacy of a new mood-stabilizing drug to lithium for reducing the risk of acute manic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder. The investigators plan to enroll 300 individuals with bipolar disorder over one year and assign them to receive either the new drug or lithium for 2 years. An interim analysis performed by the data monitoring committee 6 months after the start of the study reveals that several patients in the trial developed myocardial infarction. The results of the interim analysis for 187 participants over a 4-month period are shown:

New drug (n = 93)
Lithium (n = 94)
Relative risk (95% CI)

Incidence of a manic episode
6.4%
14.9%
0.43 (0.17, 1.07)

Incidence of myocardial infarction
4.3%
1.1%
3.90 (0.46, 35.49)

The dropout rate at the time of the interim analysis is negligible. No events of myocardial infarction were reported during phase 0 and phase 1 trials of the new drug. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial recommendation by the data monitoring committee to the principal investigator?
content_preview: A phase 2 multicenter, double-blind randomized superiority trial is performed to compare the efficacy of a new mood-stabilizing drug to lithium for reducing the risk of acute manic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder. The investigators plan to enroll 300 individuals with bipolar disorder over one year and assign them to receive either the new drug or lithium for 2 years. An interim analysis performed by the data monitoring committee 6 months after the start of the study reveals that several patients in the trial developed myocardial infarction. The results of the interim analysis for 187 participants over a 4-month period are shown: New drug (n = 93) Lithium (n = 94) Relative risk (95% CI) Incidence of a manic episode 6.4% 14.9% 0.43 (0.17, 1.07) Incidence of myocardial infarction 4.3% 1.1% 3.90 (0.46, 35.49) The dropout rate at the time of the interim analysis is negligible. No events of myocardial infarction were reported during phase 0 and phase 1 trials of the new drug. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial recommendation by the data monitoring committee to the principal investigator?
hint: Unexpected adverse events (UAEs) typically occur in phase 2 and phase 3 trials because these phases involve a large number of participants who all have the disease of interest, whereas phase 0 or phase 1 trials are typically performed on a small number of healthy individuals.
learning_objective: Interpret interim analysis results, and choose the appropriate action for unexpected serious adverse events in clinical trials.

answers.content: Discontinue the trial because of futility
answers.explanation_why: A trial may be discontinued if it is shown to be futile (i.e., unable to achieve its objectives) because of a poor enrollment rate, higher than expected dropout rate, or clearly inferior treatment efficacy. However, in this scenario, enrollment rates are acceptable (187 of 300 planned participants have already been recruited in the first 6 months), dropout rates are negligible, and the new drug does not show an inferior efficacy compared to lithium. A different recommendation is more appropriate.

answers.content: Continue the trial but inform unaffected and new participants about the risk of myocardial infarction
answers.explanation_why: If UAEs occur during a trial, it may be necessary to provide additional information both to current and new participants as part of the informed consent process. However, in this scenario, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial.

answers.content: Continue the trial because the results are not statistically significant
answers.explanation_why:
Neither result of the interim analysis is statistically significant because the 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of the relative risks cross the null value of one. Continuing the trial as planned with more participants would narrow the CIs and likely result in statistical significance. However, for UAEs (especially serious ones, such as myocardial infarction), the lack of statistical significance in an interim analysis is not a reason to continue the trial.

For expected adverse events, stopping rules, which take statistical significance and other factors into account, can help determine whether to continue a trial.

answers.content: Discontinue the trial until the reasons for myocardial infarction in the participants are clear
answers.explanation_why:
Every trial requires a monitoring plan (e.g., interim analysis by a data monitoring committee) to ensure participant safety and scientific merit. Ongoing trials are discontinued when there is evidence of futility, safety concerns, or early evidence of clear benefit. A UAE, especially if it is serious (e.g., myocardial infarction), should result in temporary discontinuation of the clinical trial (even if the risk is not statistically significant on the interim analysis) until the reasons for the event are determined.

If the adverse event is determined to be related to the trial, it may be necessary to modify the research protocol (e.g., by altering the exclusion or inclusion criteria, changing the dosing, increasing the monitoring frequency) to minimize the risk to participants. Protocol modifications need approval from the institutional review board and often require reconfirming informed consent for ongoing participation. The trial should be terminated if it is not feasible to minimize risk to an acceptable level.

answers.content: Continue the trial but exclude participants with additional risk factors for myocardial infarction
answers.explanation_why: If a UAE is shown to be related to research and restricting certain participants from the trial can reduce risk to an acceptable level, a change in the exclusion criteria (with approval from the institutional review board) may be appropriate. However, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial in this scenario.

question_text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a routine examination. In the past 6 months, the patient was hospitalized twice because of a urinary tract infection. She has Alzheimer disease, diabetes mellitus, and chronic urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. She is bedridden and lives with her daughter, who is her next of kin. Current medications include rivastigmine and metformin. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented to person and place but not to time. She can name three objects shown by the physician and recalls two after 3 minutes. She makes multiple errors during a serial sevens test. The physician suggests replacing the indwelling urinary catheter with a suprapubic catheter in order to reduce the risk of further urinary tract infections. The physician informs the patient about the procedure as well as the risks and benefits of suprapubic catheter use compared to continued transurethral catheter use. The patient is able to repeat the information in her own words. When asked for her decision, she says “I will keep the current catheter because I do not want to undergo surgery.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a routine examination. In the past 6 months, the patient was hospitalized twice because of a urinary tract infection. She has Alzheimer disease, diabetes mellitus, and chronic urinary incontinence, for which she has an indwelling urinary catheter. She is bedridden and lives with her daughter, who is her next of kin. Current medications include rivastigmine and metformin. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented to person and place but not to time. She can name three objects shown by the physician and recalls two after 3 minutes. She makes multiple errors during a serial sevens test. The physician suggests replacing the indwelling urinary catheter with a suprapubic catheter in order to reduce the risk of further urinary tract infections. The physician informs the patient about the procedure as well as the risks and benefits of suprapubic catheter use compared to continued transurethral catheter use. The patient is able to repeat the information in her own words. When asked for her decision, she says “I will keep the current catheter because I do not want to undergo surgery.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A patient has decision-making capacity when they can demonstrate an understanding of the medical information, show an appreciation of the relevant facts, communicate a choice, and express the reasoning for the choice.
learning_objective: Recognize the components of decision-making capacity and respect patient autonomy.

answers.content: Obtain consent from the daughter
answers.explanation_why: If a patient's capacity is impaired, their advance health directive should be used to guide decision-making. In the absence of an advance health care directive, a surrogate decision-maker is chosen (typically the patient's next of kin). This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

answers.content: Consult with the local ethics committee
answers.explanation_why: Consulting with an ethics committee can be useful in the case of an ethical dilemma. However, decision-making capacity should be determined by the treating physician. This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

answers.content: Consult psychiatrist for capacity evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Decision-making capacity should be determined by the treating physician, but a psychiatrist may be consulted when capacity is difficult to assess (e.g., in patients with severe mental illness). This patient has demonstrated the capacity to make her own medical decisions.

answers.content: Reassess mental status in 1 week
answers.explanation_why: A patient may be temporarily incapacitated (e.g., due to intoxication or delirium), requiring treatment before reassessment of mental status. This patient has no temporary conditions that affect her capacity to make medical decisions.

answers.content: Keep the indwelling urinary catheter in place
answers.explanation_why: Capacity assessment should be based on the individual patient and the decision being made. This patient has demonstrated all four components of decision-making capacity, and her decision should be respected. She clearly expressed an understanding of the medical information and an appreciation of the relevant facts in her own words. Furthermore, she communicated her decision to keep the indwelling transurethral catheter and gave the reasoning for her choice. Although patients with dementia may have impaired cognitive abilities, it should not be assumed that they lack decision-making capacity; their capacity to make medical decisions is often intact.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon?
content_preview: A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon?
hint: This strategy, which is also considered when prescribing biological immunosuppressants, aims to control costs and provide only the necessary care.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for prior authorization for elective procedures with HMO insurance.

answers.content: Defer knee surgery until a request for reimbursement is approved by the HMO
answers.explanation_why: Prior authorization (PA) is a process used by health insurance companies to evaluate the medical necessity and cost of medications, tests, and treatments in order to approve coverage before they are provided to the patient. Health insurance companies usually require PA for elective and expensive interventions that have lower-cost alternatives (e.g., arthroplasty). PA is obtained to ensure that the health insurance company will cover the requested care, protecting patients from financial liability. If a health care provider is in-network, they are responsible for determining whether an intervention needs PA and for submitting the request form to the health insurance company. Treatment should only be provided after the health insurance company has reviewed and approved the request.
answers.explanation_but: Many health care providers have called for reforming of the PA process because of its detrimental impact on patient care. PAs are widely considered to be a time-consuming administrative burden that can result in delays in care and adverse clinical outcomes. Submitting requests electronically can help reduce administrative time and speed up the process of obtaining PA.

answers.content: Perform the knee surgery and ask the primary care physician to submit a pre-claim review to the HMO
answers.explanation_why: A pre-claim review requests provisional confirmation of coverage after treatment but before the submission of a final claim for payment. Because total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage by the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is preferred. In addition, the treating physician is responsible for submitting a pre-claim review.

answers.content: Ask the patient to seek approval from the HMO for reimbursement prior to surgery
answers.explanation_why: Approval from the HMO is required prior to certain types of interventions, especially expensive treatments and those with lower-cost alternatives (e.g., total knee arthroplasty). However, the patient is not responsible for seeking approval for treatments given by in-network providers.

answers.content: Inform the patient that she has to pay out of pocket because HMOs do not cover elective orthopedic surgeries
answers.explanation_why: Patients with HMOs must pay out of pocket for services by out-of-network providers. However, this patient's surgeon is in-network, and HMOs cover elective orthopedic surgeries that are considered medically necessary.

answers.content: Perform the knee surgery and then submit a reimbursement claim to the HMO
answers.explanation_why: Submitting a reimbursement claim to the HMO after treatment can be considered in emergency situations. However, because a total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage from the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is more appropriate.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of vomiting and abdominal pain that radiates to his back. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medication includes enalapril and tamsulosin. Treatment with intravenous fluids and ketorolac is initiated. One day after admission, the patient becomes restless and insists on leaving the hospital to “run some errands” against the advice of his treating physician. When a resident tries to talk to him, the patient suddenly approaches her and screams, “I need to leave now!” A nearby nurse who heard the screaming calls the rapid response team. The arriving psychiatrist slowly approaches the patient without blocking the exit, introduces herself, and calmly asks why he would like to leave the hospital. The patient begins to shout at the psychiatrist and pulls out his intravenous catheter. The psychiatrist asks the patient to sit down and have a glass of water. The patient does not respond and starts mumbling and banging his head against the wall. The psychiatrist says, “I would also like for you to leave this hospital when it is possible.” The patient abruptly turns and throws one of his slippers at the psychiatrist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of vomiting and abdominal pain that radiates to his back. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medication includes enalapril and tamsulosin. Treatment with intravenous fluids and ketorolac is initiated. One day after admission, the patient becomes restless and insists on leaving the hospital to “run some errands” against the advice of his treating physician. When a resident tries to talk to him, the patient suddenly approaches her and screams, “I need to leave now!” A nearby nurse who heard the screaming calls the rapid response team. The arriving psychiatrist slowly approaches the patient without blocking the exit, introduces herself, and calmly asks why he would like to leave the hospital. The patient begins to shout at the psychiatrist and pulls out his intravenous catheter. The psychiatrist asks the patient to sit down and have a glass of water. The patient does not respond and starts mumbling and banging his head against the wall. The psychiatrist says, “I would also like for you to leave this hospital when it is possible.” The patient abruptly turns and throws one of his slippers at the psychiatrist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is agitated and violent and has not responded to verbal and nonverbal deescalation techniques.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in managing an agitated and violent patient not responding to deescalation techniques.

answers.content: Leave the patient alone and reevaluate him after 15 minutes
answers.explanation_why: Leaving this uncooperative patient alone is inappropriate because he poses an imminent threat to himself and others. Staff and patient safety should always be prioritized; therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this point.

answers.content: Administer a sedative medication intramuscularly
answers.explanation_why:
Calming medication is indicated for agitated or aggressive patients who pose a danger to themselves or others and do not respond to nonpharmacological measures. The goal of treatment is to relieve the patient's distress while permitting a safe medical and psychiatric evaluation. In uncooperative patients, parenteral administration is required. If necessary, an intramuscular medication can be used initially to calm the patient and facilitate safe intravenous access. Treatment should be based on the suspected cause and severity of symptoms (e.g., an antipsychotic with a short-acting benzodiazepine for severe agitation). If a patient is cooperative, they should be involved in choosing the medication and administration route (oral medication is preferred).

Physical restraint is sometimes necessary as a subsequent measure if calming medication and deescalation techniques have been unsuccessful and patients continue to be a danger to themselves or health care providers.

answers.content: Ask the patient about his feelings
answers.explanation_why: Noncoercive verbal techniques are appropriate for agitated patients who are otherwise cooperative. This patient is violent and has not responded to numerous verbal and nonverbal deescalation techniques, making another step in management more appropriate at this point.

answers.content: Offer the patient an oral sedative
answers.explanation_why: Offering oral sedatives is appropriate for an agitated or aggressive patient who is otherwise cooperative because giving the patient a choice may defuse the situation and prevent further escalation. However, because this patient is uncooperative and poses a danger to himself and his health care providers, another step in management is more appropriate to ensure patient and staff safety.

answers.content: Discharge the patient against medical advice
answers.explanation_why: Because this patient is uncooperative and poses a danger to himself and others, discharge against medical advice is inappropriate.

question_text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for elective surgical repair of a right-sided inguinal hernia. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension and colorectal carcinoma, for which he underwent right-sided hemicolectomy 7 years ago. His medications are metoprolol and lisinopril. Physical examination shows a soft and reducible mass in the patient's right inguinal region and a well-healed midline scar. The patient is scheduled for an open hernioplasty on the next day. The attending surgeon who will perform the procedure expects no significant complications. A fourth-year medical student who is on rotation in the surgical ward asks if she may scrub in and participate as a second assistant in the procedure. She has sufficient experience in the operating room from previous clerkships. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the attending surgeon?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for elective surgical repair of a right-sided inguinal hernia. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension and colorectal carcinoma, for which he underwent right-sided hemicolectomy 7 years ago. His medications are metoprolol and lisinopril. Physical examination shows a soft and reducible mass in the patient's right inguinal region and a well-healed midline scar. The patient is scheduled for an open hernioplasty on the next day. The attending surgeon who will perform the procedure expects no significant complications. A fourth-year medical student who is on rotation in the surgical ward asks if she may scrub in and participate as a second assistant in the procedure. She has sufficient experience in the operating room from previous clerkships. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the attending surgeon?
hint: Student participation in patient care is an important method for developing critical competencies (e.g., empathy, clinical thinking, patient management).
learning_objective: Recognize the need for informed consent regarding medical student participation in patient care.

answers.content: Allow the student to observe the procedure only
answers.explanation_why: Students are allowed to participate in patient care if certain steps to ensure patient autonomy are taken. Refusing the student's request to participate in surgery protects the patient's autonomy but neglects the surgeon's training responsibility. Therefore, the attending surgeon should take additional steps to inquire about the student's wish to participate in care.

answers.content: Allow the student to participate under supervision
answers.explanation_why: The attending surgeon is responsible for supervising student participation in patient care, especially during surgery. However, the student is not allowed to participate without the prior agreement of the patient, who has the right to refuse student involvement.

answers.content: Introduce the student as a colleague and inform the patient about her participation in the procedure
answers.explanation_why: The attending surgeon is responsible for informing the patient about the student's identity and desire to participate in care. However, using misleading terms, such as “colleague,” obscures the student's role and experience level and therefore contradicts the principles of beneficence and patient autonomy.

answers.content: Ask the student to inform the patient about her participation in the procedure
answers.explanation_why: The patient has the right to choose whether a student is involved in their care (autonomy), and the attending surgeon is responsible for providing the patient with all of the necessary information to make a decision. Therefore, it is not appropriate to ask the student to inform the patient, and the attending surgeon should take additional steps to inquire about the student's wish to participate in care.

answers.content: Disclose the student’s identity and training status to the patient and ask for consent
answers.explanation_why: Before surgery, a patient (or their surrogate) should be briefed about the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and authorize the plan. A physician should balance their responsibility to train medical students with their obligation to provide optimal care (nonmaleficence) while upholding the rights of the patient (autonomy). If a student wishes to assist in surgery, the attending surgeon should inform the patient about the student's identity and level of training, and the patient must give informed consent for participation. As with any other decision, the patient has the right to refuse student involvement in their care at any time.

question_text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician's office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with asthma 5 years ago. He has responded poorly to treatment and requires frequent visits to the physician. He has been a patient at the physician's practice for several years and is, as usual, accompanied by his single mother. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother says, “Thank you for everything you have done for my son. Would you be interested in going on a lunch date with me next week while my son is away at summer camp?” The physician is not currently in a romantic relationship and is interested in getting to know the mother better. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician's office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with asthma 5 years ago. He has responded poorly to treatment and requires frequent visits to the physician. He has been a patient at the physician's practice for several years and is, as usual, accompanied by his single mother. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother says, “Thank you for everything you have done for my son. Would you be interested in going on a lunch date with me next week while my son is away at summer camp?” The physician is not currently in a romantic relationship and is interested in getting to know the mother better. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: Going on a date with the patient's mother may lead to a romantic or sexual relationship, which would likely affect the patient's clinical treatment.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical implications of personal relationships with patients' family members.

answers.content: "I will accept your invitation under the condition that we do not discuss your son's medical care during lunch."
answers.explanation_why: In order to protect patient confidentiality, a physician should not disclose patient information to their surrogate decision-maker (e.g., a parent in the case of an unemancipated minor) in public areas (e.g., in a restaurant). However, the decision of whether it is ethical for the physician to engage in a relationship with a third party who is close to the patient is not influenced by whether or not the patient is discussed outside the care setting.

answers.content: "I will accept your invitation under the condition that the care of your son is transferred to another physician."
answers.explanation_why: A physician may choose to terminate a patient-physician relationship under specific circumstances (e.g., if the patient is abusive). Discontinuing an existing patient-physician relationship to pursue a relationship with an involved third party is patient abandonment and physician misconduct.

answers.content: “I will accept your invitation since you are not a patient of mine.”
answers.explanation_why: Whether it is ethical for a physician to engage in a romantic or sexual relationship with a third party who is close to a current patient is not determined by the fact that the third party (in this case, the patient's mother) is not directly under the physician's care.

answers.content: "I must decline your invitation because your son is still a minor."
answers.explanation_why: Whether it is ethical for a physician to engage in a romantic or sexual relationship with a third party who is close to a current patient is not determined by the fact that the patient is a minor.

answers.content: "I cannot accept your invitation because it would compromise your son's medical care."
answers.explanation_why:
Third parties often make decisions that affect the patient's health and welfare and are vulnerable to a physician's influence. Initiating a personal relationship with a third party who is close to the patient (e.g., parent, spouse, partner) and plays an integral role in the patient's medical decision-making process is therefore inappropriate as it can compromise treatment (as well as autonomy and patient privacy in patients with decision-making capacity and legal competence). Such relationships can limit the physician's objectivity, exploit the trust of the third party, and negatively affect the patient's well-being, which is why the invitation should be declined.

While romantic or sexual relationships between physicians and current patients are always unethical, physicians (excluding psychiatrists) may engage in romantic or sexual relationships with patients if more than 1–2 years have passed since termination of the patient-physician relationship. Psychiatrists are in a special position of influence over their patients and should never engage in such relationships with current or former patients.

question_text: A 55-year-old man who works as an account manager in the hospital comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pain and swelling of the penis. Initially, the patient is reluctant to disclose the mechanism of injury but then admits that it occurred during penetrative sexual intercourse at a swinger party. He says that he heard a cracking sound, which was followed by intense pain and an immediate loss of erection. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows hematoma and curving of the penis. He is diagnosed with a penile fracture and undergoes uncomplicated surgical repair. After surgery, the patient asks the physician if they could change the diagnosis in his medical records because he is ashamed that his colleagues may read them. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man who works as an account manager in the hospital comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pain and swelling of the penis. Initially, the patient is reluctant to disclose the mechanism of injury but then admits that it occurred during penetrative sexual intercourse at a swinger party. He says that he heard a cracking sound, which was followed by intense pain and an immediate loss of erection. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows hematoma and curving of the penis. He is diagnosed with a penile fracture and undergoes uncomplicated surgical repair. After surgery, the patient asks the physician if they could change the diagnosis in his medical records because he is ashamed that his colleagues may read them. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: Medical records describe a patient's medical history and the care or services provided by health care professionals and facilities, document communication between patients and providers, ensure compliance with regulations and quality standards, and serve as a business record and resource for health care reimbursement.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical obligation to maintain accurate medical records.

answers.content: Reject the patient's request
answers.explanation_why:
Medical records are legal documents; the information provided should be complete and accurate. Intentional falsification of medical records may constitute misconduct and lead to serious consequences for the physician, even if the medical care provided was appropriate. Therefore, the physician should reject the patient's request and reassure him that his records are treated confidentially.

Under HIPAA, patients can request changes to their medical records if they consider them incomplete or inaccurate by placing a formal request to the covered entity. The covered entity should correct the medical record if the information is incomplete or inadequate and when making changes, a strikethrough (i.e., a line drawn through the text) should be applied to written and/or electronic notes but still remain legible to avoid ambiguity. All amendments should be dated and signed by the covered entity.

answers.content: Request the patient to submit a formal application to the medical records department
answers.explanation_why: Patients can submit a formal application to the medical record department and request their records be changed if they consider them inaccurate or incomplete. The patient in this scenario knows that his records are accurate but asks the physician to falsify the diagnosis to avoid embarrassment. Submitting a formal request to amend records would not be helpful as the request would be denied.

answers.content: Accept the patient's request and make a time-stamped note that the record was modified
answers.explanation_why: Medical records may be modified by the physician if the information is incomplete or inaccurate. When making changes, a strikethrough (i.e., a line drawn through the text) should be applied to written and/or electronic notes but still remain legible to avoid ambiguity. All amendments should be dated and signed by the physician. Because this patient's records are accurate, it is not necessary to make changes or leave a note.

answers.content: Accept the patient's request, but inform him that the alteration will result in out-of-pocket expenses for the care provided
answers.explanation_why: Medical records are an important communication tool between health care providers and health insurance companies and serve as a resource for health care reimbursement. Alterations to medical records, if appropriate, do not result in health insurance companies not covering indicated treatment. Moreover, medical records should be complete and accurate, which cannot be bypassed by out-of-pocket payment for treatment.

answers.content: Reject the patient's request and report it to the hospital ethics committee
answers.explanation_why: The patient's request does not violate any laws or ethical principles and there is no ethical dilemma for the physician since a clear course of action is appropriate in this situation. The patient's request does not need to be reported to a supervising entity or an ethics committee.
